Document_Content: urn:contentItem:4BHK-17S0-015G-X54B-00000-00<published>2004-01-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 55</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Sick Science Moments ;<br/>Building excitement</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>with Dr Karl</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MATHEMATICIANS have made mathematical models of much of the world around us, with some of them creating models of what are called "excitable media". One example of excitable media is the dry trees and dry litter in a forest. This particular theory of excitable media describes how a forest fire starts, and then spreads.</p><p>Another example of excitable media is the set of muscles that make up your heart tissue. When they are given a little jolt of electricity, the muscles in your heart will contract.</p><p>It turns out that there are quite a few electrical abnormalities of the heart that involve problems with the excitability of the heart tissue - either it's too excitable, or it's not excitable enough. In fact, the theory of excitable media can also predict that some people will have extra heartbeats.</p><p>But it was a bit of a surprise to find that this theory of excitable media could deal with something as complicated as human behaviour - but then again, we are talking about a sports event.</p><p>You can think of a person as being an excitable unit - and that's not so unusual. This simply means that a person can be prompted into action by some sort of external stimulus. In general, the closer and more powerful the stimulus is, the more the human being, as an excitable unit, will respond.</p><p>So to explain how a Mexican wave can get started and keep rolling, each person needs only three internal rules that they obey, one after the other. First, they wait in their resting state, ready to be excited by the right stimulus. Second, when stimulated, they go through the active phase where they stand up and wave their arms. Third, they progress to the refractory phase, which is what you and I would call "sitting down again".</p><p>You now might say that this research is incredibly useless. But it is important with regard to crowd control. When you have 100,000 people at a sports event, simply moving them in and out of the stadium can be dangerous if it's not done wisely.</p><p> *  Edited insight from Dr Karl Kruszelnicki's latest book, Bumbreath, Botox and Bubbles,  published by HarperCollins.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7XHX-JRX1-2RYX-1501-00000-00Fire chief to the defence of catastrophe warning2010-01-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 5Fire chief to the defence of catastrophe warningNATASHA ROBINSON, LAUREN WILSON, ADDITIONAL REPORTING: ANGUS HOHENBOKEN

Residents ignored alerts on a day of extreme temperatures

THE NSW fire chief has strongly defended the new catastrophic fire warning as rural mayors warned there was mass confusion over the national top category of fire alert.

Large swaths of NSW and Victoria were placed on a ``code red'' catastrophic warning yesterday. But the vast majority of residents in towns across northern Victoria, the Wimmera and the NSW Riverina -- all subject to the warning -- ignored recommendations to leave their properties despite authorities warning that if fires threatened towns it would be unsafe to stay at their homes.

Temperatures reached almost 44C in parts of northern Victoria and gusty northwesterly winds pummelled the towns of Bendigo, Shepparton, Echuca, Wangaratta and Wodonga, all on code red.

In NSW, the northern, southern and eastern Riverina was placed on a catastrophic alert yesterday, together with areas of the state's southwest.

The national catastrophic category of fire alert was introduced late last year in response to the Black Saturday fires in Victoria, which killed 173 people.

Following criticism from former NSW fire chief Phil Koperberg that the catastrophic warning could cause unnecessary panic, NSW Rural Fire Service commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons yesterday described the new warning system as a ``tremendous leap forward''.

``The stark message that came out of that terrible tragedy in Victoria is the need for simple language to explain to people what the risk is based on what we know,'' Mr Fitzsimmons said.

``I make no apology for being blunt in advising communities of their risk when it comes to fire and associated fire weather.''

The mayors of Deniliquin, Griffith and Young in the NSW Riverina region and Bendigo in Victoria -- none of which had fires burning close by yesterday -- said there had been no move by residents to leave their homes and warned of widespread confusion over the catastrophic warning.

The debate about the merits of the catastrophic rating came as firefighters tamed a bushfire that had been burning out of control in southeastern Victoria last night, threatening the townships of Cann River and Lower Tonghi.

The forest fire in the Croajingolong National Park in the state's Gippsland region jumped containment lines yesterday afternoon but the fire warning was downgraded to ``watch and act'' about 7pm. The efforts of firefighters were made difficult by an ``incredibly volatile'' cold front that moved through Victoria late yesterday.

The cool change nonetheless brought relief to Melburnians who sweltered through what was the state's equal-hottest night in recorded history.

The mercury topped 35C at midnight and only dropped to 30.6C after 8am yesterday.

The sizzling evening equalled the state's record reached on February 1, 1902, but still fell a few degrees short of Adelaide's hottest ever night, reached in January last year when temperatures failed to fall below 33C.

While Melbourne gained relief, Sydney sweltered yesterday with the temperature nudging past 40C in the city's west.

urn:contentItem:49NV-F130-01S8-H4VB-00000-00<published>1995-07-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Greece counts the cost of forest inferno</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>-SOURCE- Reuters, AFP</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ATHENS: A huge forest fire which had raged through the outskirts of Athens for the last three days, gutting homes and destroying woodland, had been brought under partial control, the Greek fire brigade said yesterday."The blaze is under partial control but many units remain in the area to make sure the wind does not fan any new fronts," a fire department spokesman, Mr Panayotis Liotos, said.</p><p>"We believe we will fully control it very soon." Agriculture Ministry general secretary Mr Yannis Sbokos said: "The fire will soon be extinguished." As gale winds eased, Greek, French and Italian planes bombarded the blaze with tonnes of water.Five helicopters from Germany were due to join the fight later in the day after the Greek Government asked for urgent help from the European Union.The region north-east of Athens, where thousands have been evacuated, has been declared a disaster area.Military units were drafted to help firemen and residents fight flames driving through thick pine forest."Of course they will bring it under control . . . there is nothing else left to burn," said one resident whose house in the Drafi area was destroyed yesterday."The fire engines came in hours late when everything was already finished." Agriculture Minister Mr George Moraitis said at least 4000ha of forest had been destroyed along with 30 houses and other buildings. Residents said a minimum of 80 houses had been gutted."It is a biblical, disastrous fire with a 20km front," Prime Minister Mr Andreas Papandreou said yesterday."It has been 50 years since we had something like this in the Athens area." Thousands of people were evacuated from houses, hospitals and summer camps and 20 people injured, none seriously.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4MPM-J1V0-TX4S-M2RF-00000-00More rainfall likely but greenhouse effect won't lessen: experts2007-01-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisAPg. 3More rainfall likely but greenhouse effect won't lessen: expertsGillian Lord

There's good news and there's bad news.

The good news is that experts predict the end of the drought is in sight, with a weakening in the El Nino effect expected to cause a return to normal rainfall patterns in 2007. The bad news is that it doesn't mean the greenhouse effect will reduce.

The Bureau of Meteorology says the signs are that El Nino will peak around January and February, and after that will weaken.

National Climate Centre head Michael Coughlan says that once the El Nino peaks, its effects fade fairly quickly over Australia. Of course there are no guarantees, but indicators include the Southern Oscillation Index, which is negative during an El Nino event, has moved back to positive.

However, former head of CSIRO's climate modelling program Barrie Hunt warns that a return to normal rainfall does not mean that the greenhouse effect is lessening.

And a joint study by CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology into the climate change impact on fire weather revealed that Canberra could expect a marked increase in the annual average of very high or extreme fire danger days by 2050.

The study found the danger was likely to increase from the current 23.1 days to an annual average of 27.9-38.3 days by 2050. The new report, intended to help south-east Australian communities prepare for any increased risk of fire which may result from climate change, found that nationally the combined frequencies of days with very high and extreme Forest Fire Danger Index ratings were likely to increase by 15 to 70 per cent by 2050.

Going back to the good news, while last year was Australia's hottest on record, 2007 is likely to rate about 10th on the list. Any return to normal rainfall will be welcome in the national capital, which experienced its hottest spring on record and its second-lowest total rainfall.

Last year was a doubly unlucky one for Australia, Clem Davis, from Canberra's Bureau of Meteorology, said. "But last year's El Nino was quite late and quite mild," he said.

"I think Australia was impacted by the fact that we had cool waters over the Indian Ocean as well as El Nino, so it was a double-whammy effect.

Australia is put in a higher pressure situation in El Nino, and when it breaks down you get normal weather patterns in late summer and autumn.

"El Nino usually breaks down in autumn. This usually means moisture being dragged down from the tropics and a return to a more normal rainfall situation. So on that basis you'd anticipate a return to a more normal rainfall in autumn."

urn:contentItem:6F7D-FNP3-RV30-R3RN-00000-00RESIDENTS GO HOME AS FIRE DOUSED1995-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisPg. 12RESIDENTS GO HOME AS FIRE DOUSED

KEYWORD-HIT Residents go home as fire doused NEW YORK: Evacuees were allowed back home yesterday as exhausted firefighters cleaned up a wind-driven forest fire that had threatened high-priced Eastport beach resort communities in New York State. Authorities said the 2400ha blaze looked like arson, and critics asked why promised federal airplanes to bomb the fire with water did not arrive until yesterday. Bulldozers were used to create a dirt ring around the perimeter of the 8km by 2.5km fire zone. Nonetheless, officials baulked at declaring the fire contained because of the slight chance that it could flare up again without warning in the midst of million-dollar real estate. The area has not had rain in 19 days. About 40 firefighters had an assortment of minor injuries. However, the blaze, feeding on tinder-dry pines and oaks 110km east of New York City, destroyed one home and a timber yard, damaged seven other homes and a train station, and shut down railways and roads. Soon after noon yesterday, 400 evacuated Westhampton residents went home. Some spent two nights sleeping in high school gyms or their cars. Joseph Monteith, Suffolk County Police chief, said arson was suspected in the blaze that started on Thursday. Two other fires were reported that night along Long Island's south shore, and a police task force was investigating if they were linked to the larger blaze. The fire won't be officially declared under control for at least three or four days. The area will be surveyed with an airborne infrared detector to ensure that every hot spot and ember is extinguished. Associated Press REST at last . . . firefighters in Suffolk County, New York State, take a breather after fighting forest fires which raged through their area since Thursday.

urn:contentItem:5B6H-2N41-JD34-V06W-00000-00Grand ambitions2014-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMCulturePg. 14Grand ambitionsAnimation FILM REVIEWSPAUL BYRNES

WALKING WITH DINOSAURS:

THE MOVIE

Directed by Barry Cook and

Neil Nightingale

Rated PG, 87 minutes

RATING: 3/5

Stunning scenery and effects are undermined by a cloying story, writes PAUL BYRNES.

Making natural history films for children has its challenges. There is the unpleasant fact that creatures eat each other to survive, not to mention reproduction. "What are they doing mummy?" asks the unsuspecting toddler. The answers are sometimes complicated.

A bigger problem is the commitment to truth. With a movie that has the name BBC Earth stamped on it, there is a duty to scientific accuracy, and that runs headlong into a duty to make a buck. In Walking with Dinosaurs, making a buck wins.

Starting from the basis of a successful documentary series made in 1999, the feature film has been shaped and reshaped to make it more appealing for North American kids. In a sense, that is fair enough, because the story takes place in North America, albeit 70 million years ago, when dinosaurs ruled the Earth. Except that they didn't: no one and no thing ruled Earth, but let's not get into that.

The story follows a small pachyrhinosaurus named Patchi (voiced by Justin Long) who has to survive the loss of some of his family, a scary migration across the Alaskan wilderness, and big adventures such as falling in love with another cute pachyrhinosaurus called Juniper (Tiya Sircar). Patchi's constant companion is a talkative prehistoric bird called Alex, who speaks with a Mexican accent (John Leguizamo). That's also fair, because the species Alexornis was first discovered in Baja, Mexico.

Each species of dinosaur is introduced formally, with a freeze frame, a scientific name, and a description of its eating habits. The pachyrhinosaurus is a herbivore, but Patchi is grabbed as a baby by a Troodon, an omnivore with sharp teeth, who puts a hole in the bony frill at the top of his skull. Patchi is thus instantly recognisable in his herd, because he has a hole that makes a noise when the wind whistles through it (and yes, I'm sure some of the double entendres in the film are intentional).

The backgrounds were filmed in Alaska and New Zealand, to get settings that looked like Earth of 70 million years ago. Many of these are stunning, as is the dinosaur animation. But even with a great deal of scientific accuracy behind it, the film becomes cloyingly anthropomorphic.

The dinosaurs have feelings, they talk in modern American parlance and their family dynamics are just like ours (i.e. American, nuclear). Yes, of course it makes the dinosaurs more appealing to children, and yes, there is a century-old tradition of anthropomorphism in films for children, but doing it the old way isn't the only way, or always the best way. What's frustrating is that the film set out to be much better than it is.

It was originally going to be a silent film, without dialogue or narration. The dinosaurs didn't make wisecracks and the storytelling was to be entirely visual, with a strong musical score. Somewhere along the line, that changed. The dinosaurs didn't just start to talk, they got names, and the script (credited to the experienced John Collee) was stretched over "the hero's journey", like so many others. The designers, albeit with a team of palaeontologists watching, were told to make the dinosaurs cuter, with bigger eyes and more kid-friendly features.

I'm not sure who drove this process. Apart from BBC Earth, the partners in the film include Reliance Entertainment, an Indian conglomerate with vast wealth behind it, and Animal Logic, the Australian effects and animation house. The co-directors are Barry Cook, an experienced American animator (co-director of Mulan) and Neil Nightingale, the head of BBC Earth, the new marketing name for the BBC's natural history brand. Nightingale is a former head of the natural history unit, with a first-class degree from Oxford in zoology. We may assume that Cook took charge of the animation side, and Nightingale tried to keep it real, with educational value, and yet profitable.

The educational value is compromised. Children with an interest in dinosaurs will get some superb, thrilling sequences that are close to what we know about certain species. The younger viewers will think dinosaurs could talk, and that they were cute and playful and warm-blooded. They will also find some of the episodes quite scary, as when a forest fire almost engulfs Patchi. The narration warns us when things are heading in that direction, which is reassuring.

For its grandeur, the film deserves praise. It has great sweep, made more powerful by the addition of 3D. For its lack of nerve, its unwillingness to be the film it set out to be, and for underestimating the intelligence of modern children, it deserves less praise.Twitter: @ptbyrnes

PHOTO: Meet cute: The tale's hero, Patchi (voiced by Justin Long), meets feathered friend Alex (John Leguizamo).

urn:contentItem:44J4-59M0-015G-P1N2-00000-00<published>2001-08-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 9</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bushfire deaths lead to murder charges</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Robert Lusetich  * Los Angeles correspondent</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CALIFORNIAN prosecutors have filed murder charges against a man who allegedly lit an illegal camp fire which started a bushfire and ultimately caused two pilots dropping fire retardant to crash to their deaths.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The fire, near Hopland, about 160km north of San Francisco, ravaged 101ha and needed more than 1000 firefighters to contain it.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Prosecutors allege Frank Brady, 50, might have been running an illegal drug laboratory in the remote forest area where he had lit the camp fire. A second man, Richard Mortenson, 43, is also believed to have been involved in starting the fire. Mr Mortenson was arrested after police found a string of outstanding warrants for drug and weapons charges.</p><p>Mendocino County District Attorney Norman Vroman said he was also considering laying murder charges against Mr Mortenson. If convicted, the men would face 15 years in jail.</p><p> "We will prosecute everybody involved as much as I can prosecute them for as many things as I can charge them with," Mr Vroman said.</p><p> Evidence of a methamphetamine production lab was discovered near where the forest fire began, Mr Vroman added.</p><p> Larry Groff, 55, and Lars Stratte, 45, died hours after the blaze began on Tuesday, Australian time, after their 1950s-era Grumman tankers collided in mid-air.</p><p> Investigators believe they did not see each other because of thick smoke and that their aircraft clipped during a pass over.</p><p> Both were experienced pilots who had worked in firefighting for a number of years.</p><p> Dry, extremely hot weather throughout the US for the past week has created conditions conducive to bushfires. A number have broken out in California, including a 728ha fire that came within metres of expensive homes in the hills just north of Los Angeles.</p><p> Police are investigating whether that fire was deliberately lit. Another fire, which threatened hundreds of homes in the western suburbs of Los Angeles at the weekend, was started by children playing with matches.</p><p> In Montana, park rangers have closed large parts of Glacier National Park as firefighters fight to contain a 7288ha bushfire, started by lightning strikes.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P8B-H1Y0-TXN5-R1C3-00000-00Reality is good, says father of the Net2001-03-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisBUSINESSBizcomPg. 24Reality is good, says father of the NetSue Lowe

Dr Vinton Cerf, often referred to as the "father of the Internet", has described the dot com wreckage as a healthy dose of "reality therapy".

In the 1960s Dr Cerf was one of two US scientists said to have used the back of an envelope to sketch out an "interesting research problem" that later became the global Internet.

He also lent his name to endless abuse when he launched the "Cerfing the Internet" campaign in 1989.

But unlike many of the academic figures of the early Internet, Dr Cerf has always keenly supported its commercialisation. As a senior executive at global communications giant, MCI WorldCom, he has retained a very active position in developing the technical architecture to support global e-commerce.

In the face of vast numbers of struggling and dying Internet businesses, Dr Cerf defends the technology against poor business practices.

"The `dot bomb' situation is far from a commercial collapse of the Internet," he said.

"Rather, it is proof that 20th century business principles are still relevant. You should make more money than you spend to keep your business in operation."

"I think the dose of reality therapy for the Internet market is a good thing, rather like a forest fire that we now know is healthy," he said.

"It means that capital will go to companies with good business models, not just `something related to the Internet'. That's good news for people with good business ideas."

In Melbourne this week to attend the quarterly board meeting of the international body, the Internet Corporation for Assigning Names and Numbers (ICANN), Dr Cerf highlighted the "very hard" technical problems inherent in the current push to de-Americanise the Internet by adding support for non-roman alphabets.

"Some people speak about internationalisation issues as if it were simply a matter of policy, or simply a matter of becoming more culturally aware," he said.

"This is a terrible oversimplification.

"There are serious problems almost everywhere you look. Some of them really interfere with interoperability on the Internet and that is the single most important value of the existing Internet standards."

Illus: Dr Cerf

urn:contentItem:59X7-FYD1-JD34-V1D1-00000-00Beware the Black Header - A recipe for disaster2013-11-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisCOUNTPg. 20Beware the Black Header - A recipe for disasterDale Grey, DEPI

REGION - The 2013 harvest has been going for a few weeks now in some areas, so it's not before time to reiterate the importance of header safety.

Since time began these machines and fire have never gelled.

Running a metallic machine at thousands of revs a minute and at hundreds of degrees in an environment full of super dry tinder is a recipe for problems.

Recent research by Kondinin suggests seven per cent of headers each year cause a fire and 10 percent of those fires cause damage to the machine or crop.

Grains Research and Development Corporation data says 12 machines bite the dust in Australia each year. My personal gut feel is that could be an underestimate.

Fortunately, most fires are discovered early and are put out, giving the owners/operators a minor heart attack at the time.

Just about all of us have smelt something and found a patch of charred chaff around a dead bearing at some time in our life.

My dad used to tell us boys to walk around the header at every box unloading to the mother bin, but if you're on the go unloading with chaser bins, you have to be more disciplined.

The GRDC has recently produced a handy back pocket guide Reducing Harvest Fire Risk by agricultural engineer Dr Graeme Quick.

It has 10 key points to consider:

Recognise the big four factors that contribute to fires: relative humidity, ambient temperature, wind and crop type and conditions. Stop harvest when the danger is extreme.

Focus on service, maintenance and machine hygiene at harvest on the days more hazardous for fire. Follow systematic preparation and prevention procedures.

Use every means possible to avoid the accumulation of flammable material on the manifold, turbocharger or the exhaust system.

Be aware of side and tail winds that can disrupt the radiator fan air blast that normally keeps the exhaust area clean.

Be on the lookout for places where chafing can occur such as fuel lines, battery cables, hot wires, tyres, drive belts etc.

Avoid overloading electrical circuits. Don't replace a blown fuse with a higher amperage one. It is your only protection against wiring damage from shorts and overloading.

Periodically check bearings around the front and the machine body. Use a hand-held digital heat-measuring gun for temperature diagnostics on bearings, brakes etc.

Drag chains, or better still drag cables or grounding conductors, may help dissipate electrical charge (or static), but are not universally successful in all conditions. There are some invaluable fire-suppressing options on the market.

Use the battery isolation switch when the harvester is parked. Use vermin deterrents in the cab and elsewhere, as vermin chew some types of electrical insulation.

Observe the Grassland Fire Danger Index (GFDI) protocol on high fire risk days. Maintain two-way or mobile phone contact with base and others. Keep an eye out for hazards on machinery during the season.

The SA Country fire Service (CFS) and WA Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES) have rules in place for harvest ceasing when your local GFDI exceeds 35 (in the Very High fire danger category).

The GFDI is calculated using the dryness of the fuel, the fuel load, the temperature, the relative humidity and the wind speed. When harvesting, wind speed is the factor that can make a small fire into a big one.

Slightly different methodology is used to calculate the Forest Fire Danger Index for treed areas that includes an estimate of soil moisture.

They believe that when a fire occurs in these conditions it will get away with what most farmers have on hand to control it. If you are from the other states the figure of 35 is still a good standard to work by.

Such conditions could occur when a 2t/ha wheat crop is completely dry, the temperature is 40 degrees Celsius, relative humidity is dry at eight per cent and the wind is going at 30km/h, but many other combinations are possible.

In Victoria, the daily ratings are posted by the CFA and BoM: www.cfa.vic.gov.au/warnings-restrictions/total-fire-bans-andratings/   www.bom.gov.au/vic/forecasts/bushfire.shtml

The BoM displays prediction maps of the maximum GFDI for the current day: www.bom.gov.au/vic/forecasts/fire-map.shtml

It's up to you to work out the actual location GFDI and for that you need a calculator and a data source. Those hand held meters for spray conditions fit the bill nicely and at a pinch your local automatic weather station.

Use the Macarthur Grass Fire Danger Index Mk 5 on web or in an app, (warning the FFDI is unreliable in this app).

It's much easier to sight a black header than a black panther over summer, limit the chances of yours becoming a metal merchant's delight.

urn:contentItem:3ST7-BMV0-0048-T4M3-00000-00<published>1998-05-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: WATERBOMBS NO USE IN INDONESIA FIRE FIGHTING EFFORTS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Nick Edwards</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SINGAPORE, May 28 Reuters - The millions of dollars spent waterbombing forest fires raging out of control in Indonesia are a waste of money, the leader of an international firefighting effort said today.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "It is a waste of money to use aircraft. You don't (beat) a fire by waterbombing," Ludwig Schindler, team leader of Integrated Forest Fire Management (IFFM), told Reuters.</p><p>Millions of dollars in international aid were poured into airborne efforts to quench blazes experts reckon devastated 4.5 million hectares of forest in 1997.</p><p> But Schindler said helicopters and planes spraying thousands of gallons of water over the smouldering forests was useless.</p><p> "Helicopter pilots cannot tell where the fires are most of the time, the smoke is just too thick," he said.</p><p> "When they release the water on an area where they think the fire is, they might put out 90 per cent of the fire, but 10 per cent goes on burning," spreading rapidly, Schindler said.</p><p> It costs about US$1,300 ($ A2,100) an hour to mount a helicopter waterbombing run and more than double that for a plane.</p><p> The economic cost of the fires and their resultant polluting smog is huge. Experts think the total bill for Southeast Asian economies in 1997 and 1998 could be as much as $ US6 billion ($ A9.7b).</p><p> In crisis-hit Indonesia, whose currency has plunged about 80 per cent against the US dollar since a year ago, the cost of fighting the fires has hurt progress as priority has been given to rebuilding the economy.</p><p> Foreign governments and international agencies though have pledged more than US$10 million ($ A16.2m) to battle the blazes. The United Nations Environment Program plans to spend about $ US3 million ($ A4.85m) on helicopter missions to douse the flames in 1998.</p><p> But Schindler, who heads the German-funded, Kalimantan-based IFFM, said the money would be better spent on hand tools, shovels, rakes, picks, swatters, axes, portable pumps and hoses.</p><p>REUTERS was</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3ST7-BMV0-0048-T4M3-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-25</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="331"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. (KOREA FLOODS SECOND NIGHTLEAD)</p><p nitf:lede="true">SINGAPORE, Aug 6 Reuters - Nick Leeson, the former futures trader whose deals in Singapore brought down Britain's oldest merchant bank, Barings, is seriously ill with cancer, the British High Commission said today.</p><p>(SINGAPORE LEESON LEAD)</p><p> BEIJING, Aug 6 AAP - China's Three Gorges dam would not prevent a repetition of floods which had devastated provinces along the Yangtze river, critics of the $ A35 billion project said today. (CHINA FLOODS GORGE)</p><p> KABUL, Aug 6 AFP - Taliban and opposition forces were today locked in a standoff over northern Afghanistan with both sides gearing up for heavy fighting, officials said. (AFGHAN FIGHTING NIGHTLEAD)</p><p> SRINAGAR, India, Aug 6 AFP - Artillery fell silent on India and Pakistan's disputed Kashmir border today after a week of shelling which left more than 120 dead, India officials said. (KASHMIR. See also KASHMIRINDIA GENERAL)</p><p>PORT MORESBY, Aug 6 AAP - The newly appointed governor of Papua New Guinea's Central Bank tonight assured the public of the independence of the Bank of PNG, as debate here continued over the country's rocky economy. (PNG ECONOMY NIGHTLEAD)</p><p> ATHENS, Aug 6 AFP - A new forest fire broke out at dawn today near ancient Olympia, home of the Olympic games of antiquity, firemen said. (GREECE FIRES NIGHTLEAD)</p><p> SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug 6 AP - Todor Zhivkov, Bulgaria's longtime Communist dictator and the last surviving Soviet-bloc Stalinist leader, has died, the state news agency BTA reported today. He was 86. (BULGARIA ZHIVKOV OBIT)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3TB4-BCH0-0048-T122-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-25</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="309"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:459X-TKC0-0197-B284-00000-00<published>1998-04-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 5</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BURNT FARMERS CALL FOR AID</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>KAREN GUNTHER</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SIMPSON farmers burnt in February bushfires are bracing for a showdown with the State Government over damage they claim has set them back three months.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> A band of 12 farmers affected by the Jancourt Forest fires want the government to take some responsibility for damage caused to fencing and pasture.</p><p>"We've effectively lost three months of production," dairy farmer Rob Leishman said. "That's a quarter of a season you can wipe out."</p><p> About 30 kilometres of boundary fencing and many kilometres of internal fencing were burnt in the fires which police claim were deliberately lit. Farmers are tallying the final damage, but estimate it has cost $2000 a kilometre to replace the fencing which was not insured.</p><p> "We know we can insure the fencing, but you pay a high premium if you join forestry, and why should we have to take on the whole cost?" Mr Leishman asked. "Why shouldn't the (Department of Natural Resources and Environment) take on some of the cost?"</p><p> Radiant heat also destroyed hectares of pasture on some farms directly abutting the forest. This is being resown at an average cost of about $30 a hectare, excluding labor costs.</p><p> Dairy farmer Tony Mallon was among the worst affected, losing about 50 of his 180 hectares of pasture.</p><p> "It's not just the cost of replacing the pasture that hurts. You've got to feed (the cows) something else and you've got to have the time to do," he said.</p><p> Dairy farmer Bill McLennan, whose property adjoins the Jancourt Forest, said he had kept a government road on his fenceline cleared, but knew other forest fire access tracks had not fared so well.</p><p> But DNRE south-west regional manager Paul Mainey said it was not government policy to compensate for boundary fencing destroyed by fire.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4TRP-HTS0-TXX1-F0G3-00000-00Childs play again - but it hasn't been easy2008-09-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 95Childs play again - but it hasn't been easySALLY BROWNE

After being struck down by illness, Toni Childs is back to her best, says SALLY BROWNE

SHE looks exactly the same. But Toni Childs has been on quite a journey.

In the early 1990s, the US singer had the world at her feet. Her debut album, Union, (1988) was an international hit, spawning such memorable songs as Stop Your Fussin' and Don't Walk Away. I've Got To Go Now from her second album, House of Hope, was a No. 5 in Australia.

Her powerful voice and soulful tunes cut to the heart of the public and in 1988 she was nominated for two Grammy awards. Although she didn't win, she delivered a memorable performance.

While working on a fourth album, Childs plunged herself into charity work, starting the Dream a Dolphin cause for sick kids.

It was then she discovered that she, too, was sick. She had a disease she had never heard of - Grave's Disease - a thyroid condition brought on from stress.

She went to a doctor who told her her resting pulse rate was 120 beats per minute and immediately put her on heart inhibitors. ``It was a shock because the doctors said I had to dismantle my life,'' Childs says. She put the brakes on work and focused on getting well. She describes the experience as a forest fire. ``It takes everything down,'' she says. ``And then all your bits start coming back together and it's wonderful.

``It gives you this amazing appreciation for life and the privilege of getting to do what you really love.''

What she really loves is music - and Childs finally has a new album due out. It's titled, aptly, Keep the Faith.

It was a serendipitous meeting that led her back to the recording studio. Childs was performing in a local production of the Vagina Monologues and it just so happened that Eve Ensler, the creator of that play, was in the audience. She sought Childs out after the show.

What came next was a deep bonding experience for both women. Ensler told her that her record, Union, had had a profound impact on her life.

When Ensler was down in the dumps and living out of her car, she listened to the record over and over again.

She took Childs aside and told her she needed to start singing again.

``She said, `You know what, Toni, you need to be singing. This is your gift. Why aren't you singing?' She really gave me a hard time,'' Childs says.

``And then she asked me the craziest thing: `OK, I want you to write an anthem that will inspire people to end violence against women and children for all time'.''

Childs ended up writing the song Because You're Beautiful for Ensler's documentary Until The Violence Stops. The song won an Emmy award.

Her new mood on life is summed up on the new single, One Life.

Keep the Faith is out now. Toni Childs plays The Governor Hindmarsh on September 30. Bookings: 8340 0744 or Venuetix.

urn:contentItem:4THH-CCN0-TX5N-00DM-00000-00Fired-up Childs is back2008-09-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisSCENEPg. 60Fired-up Childs is back

UNSTOPPABLE American singer-songwriter Toni Childs is back with an emotionally hard hitting new album titled Keep The Faith.

Childs will unleash her new songs, a blend of roots, rock and folk gospel, at Twin Towns on Saturday night.

Best known for her heavily R&B-influenced track Don't Walk Away, Childs hit the big time in 1988 when her debut album Union went double platinum in Australia.

Twenty years later, Keep The Faith is her fourth studio album.

It contains the powerful Because You're Beautiful which earned her a 2004 Emmy Award for best music and lyrics, and fresh pop ballad, One Life.

Childs, who ran away from home when she was 15 to pursue a career as a singer-songwriter after seeing Pink Floyd in concert, has a talent for picking the mood of the times.

Her new projects demonstrate her enormous soul and vision.

``The best part of re-emerging from the darkness and learning to embrace music once again is simply the opportunity to evolve and get down to the core of my purpose,'' she said.

``It's been a really wonderful journey. I feel like I'm a phoenix rising. I burned down to an ash and then came through that forest fire healthier and stronger than ever before.

``This album is a real departure from my other work in that it is a much more basic and rootsy collection of music.''

``Every song is written on guitar, instead of being driven by drum loops and sequencers like it was when I made my first two records.''

* FRESH from a successful sell-out tour of India over New Year and having just returned from a fifth tour of New Zealand as well as Thailand and Singapore, The Vegas Legends Show is at Club Banora on Saturday.

The show features Australia's top cabaret impersonators Kerry James and Daniel Gold. Audiences who have flocked to the two-hour blockbuster show during the past three years have gone home shaking their heads at the remarkable resemblances and vocal likenesses of the many characters portrayed.

Kerry James' impersonations of Tina Turner, Liza Minnelli, Cher, Dolly Parton, Marilyn Monroe and other Vegas Legends have been described as `just freakish' by British media.

Kerry has toured Europe, the US, the Middle East and the UK, and has worked alongside some of the biggest names in the business, including The Hollies, Tony Bennett and Jerry Lewis.

Daniel Gold's penchant for impersonating comedians is amazing. Switching from Austin Powers to Dean Martin to Jerry Lewis to Johnny Cash to Frank Sinatra, and then instantly becoming The King of rock 'n' roll, Elvis Presley, he leaves audiences spellbound with his quick fire repartee and amazing vocals.

With immaculate costuming, and backed by superbly arranged musical sequences, The Vegas Legends Show is musically brilliant, raucously funny and sometimes a little irreverent.

l Toni Childs plays Twin Towns at 8.30pm on Saturday. Tickets $45. The Vegas Legends Show, Club Banora, Saturday 8pm. No cover charge. To book or for more information call 5536 2277, or visit www.twintowns. com.au.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: FIRES RAGE ACROSS THAILAND</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BANGKOK, March 15 AFP - Fires were raging across Thailand's tinder-dry central and western provinces today although forestry officials said they were gradually gaining the upper hand.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The fires, some of which have been burning in World Heritage-listed forests since December, were about 60 per cent "under control" according to Forest Fire Control Division director Kaew Lorpattanakasem.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> He said most of the blazes had been checked but others in more difficult terrain were proving almost impossible to put out.</p><p>Fires raging out of control on the Thai-Myanmar border have forced Thai Airways flights to be rescheduled and filled local hospitals with people suffering from respiratory and other smoke-related ailments over the past three days.</p><p> Many fires have been burning for weeks in the drought-stricken northern province of Mae Hong Son and in forest reserves in several central provinces.</p><p> One fire in the World Heritage-listed Huay Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary, central Thailand, has been burning since December and has so far destroyed 3,040 hectares of jungle.</p><p> The fires, which have intesified in recent weeks as dry conditions persist, claimed 400 hectares in the past week alone, according to officials.</p><p> The Huay Kha Khaeng forest covers about 276,800 hectares across four central provinces.</p><p> The fires have been blamed on dry weather resulting from the El Nino weather phenomenon and human activities, including land clearing, farming and hunting.</p><p> Kaew said reports in the local press that 20 volunteer firefighters had gone missing for two days while battling forest blazes in western Thailand's Kanchanaburi province were inaccurate.</p><p> He said the group had enough food and water to last two days and had contacted fire control centres in Kanchanaburi province yesterday giving their precise position.</p><p> The Nation daily today reported that a land and air search had been launched to find the missing volunteers, who had no supplies or camping equipment.</p><p>AFP shb</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:459P-KJR0-0197-T1JC-00000-00<published>1998-03-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Refugees bombed</p><p nitf:lede="true">A RAIDING party allied with Burma's military government fired more</p><p nitf:lede="true">than 10 mortar rounds yesterday into a refugee camp in Thailand</p><p nitf:lede="true">sheltering 30,000 people, a Thai general said. Casualty figures were</p><p nitf:lede="true">not immediately available. Thai soldiers fired back artillery rounds</p><p nitf:lede="true">to drive off the attackers shelling the Mae Hla refugee camp.</p><p>Fires rage</p><p>OFFICIALS in the remote Amazon state of Roraima pleaded yesterday with</p><p>a federal envoy for emergency funding to fight bushfires which have</p><p>charred about 57,000 sq km since mid-January _ about a quarter of the</p><p>state's forests. Fires raging since December in World Heritage-listed</p><p>forests across Thailand's tinder-dry central and western provinces</p><p>were about 60% "under control" by yesterday, according to the Forest</p><p>Fire Control Division.</p><p>Ferry disaster</p><p>THE death toll in a river mishap during a tropical storm in southern</p><p>Bangladesh late last week rose to 25 after more bodies were recovered</p><p>from two submerged ferries yesterday. At least 30 are still</p><p>unaccounted for.</p><p>March on war</p><p>KOSOVOAlbanian women are planning a protest march today linking the</p><p>capital of the troubled Serb province to the region of Drenica. The</p><p>women will march to Drenica where some of the most violent clashes</p><p>took place earlier this month between Albanians and Serb authorities.</p><p>Baby battle</p><p>With more people dying than being born, the Greece Health Ministry</p><p>yesterday said it has ordered a government panel to examine medical</p><p>solutions for barren couples. NATO allies Greece and Turkey have</p><p>nearly gone to war three times in the past 24 years _ and Greeks worry</p><p>that Turkey's burgeoning birth rate will put it at a military</p><p>disadvantage.</p><p>Condom campaign</p><p>CHINA, the world's most populous nation, will establish a nationwide</p><p>chain of contraceptives stores targeting the vast number of people too</p><p>bashful to buy their condoms, creams and pills in ordinary chemist</p><p>shops, the official media in Beijing reported yesterday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4F7G-KT50-015G-S0VS-00000-00<published>2005-01-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 5</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Furious speed of grassland fires - BLACK TUESDAY BUSHFIRES</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BRAF CLIFTON, REBECCA KIRKWOOD</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE victims were probably caught unaware by the flames because of the speed and ferocity with which they travelled through grassland, experts said yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Given the right conditions, grass fires can spread twice as fast as bushfires and some victims may have mistakenly believed they could evade them.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Eyre Peninsula fire travelled "frighteningly fast", NSW Rural Fire Service Commissioner Phil Koperberg said yesterday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>It was a different type of blaze to the bushfires generally seen around Sydney, he added.</p><p>Very severe weather conditions, combined with the landscape of dry grassland and scrub, was to blame for Tuesday's devastation.</p><p>"In general terms, for a given set of weather conditions, a grass fire will spread twice as fast as a forest fire," CSIRO senior research scientist Phil Cheney said yesterday.</p><p>"That's under extreme conditions, with very strong winds upwards of 20km/h." Mr Cheney said it was possible the victims did not believe they were in much danger until the very last moments.</p><p>"One of the difficult things for people in the path of the fire is knowing just where it is and where it's going, and very often they don't appreciate how close it is until it's virtually upon them," he said.</p><p>"The reaction of people in the forest is that they either know intuitively, or have been told, that if they get caught in the forest they don't have a hell of a lot of a chance.</p><p>"Whereas with a grass fire, there are people who are probably more familiar with the slower spreading ones and the flames don't appear all that dangerous, and when they get these very fast-spreading ones, suddenly it takes them by surprise." The extra fuel associated with fires in the bush results in flames travelling more slowly.</p><p>However, out in the open and exposed to dangerously high winds, grass fires can spread great distances in a short time.</p><p>"It's largely to do with the size of the individual particles, the average size of which are generally larger in the forest," Mr Cheney said.</p><p>"Grass fires are also out in the open and exposed to the full strength of the wind near the ground, and the fires respond accordingly." The speed of grassland fires was experienced recently in NSW.</p><p>The Parkes telescope was threatened by a blaze on December 2, with the grass fire coming within a kilometre of the historic landmark.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:57MG-63H1-F0J6-J04K-00000-00Climate change#nl#CLIMATE Chan...2013-01-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisPg. 18Climate change#nl#CLIMATE Chan...Felicity Kirkpatric

Climate change

CLIMATE Change Minister Cassy O'Connor's letter on climate change (Letters, January 22) follows a predictable script. But then, it would, wouldn't it?

She accuses Martin Stevenson (In Black and White, January 17) of ``ignoring the bleeding obvious" and says that she has spoken to ``the esteemed thinkers" of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

She recommends that Mr Stevenson read the IPCC's Fourth Assessment Report Summary, but I don't think that he will; I know that I wouldn't because the masses of figures will prove whatever the IPCC wants them to prove.

In short, I don't trust the IPCC's figures as far as I can throw them and haven't since the recent talkfest in Copenhagen when all the northern airports froze and the eminent persons were frozen into their luxury hotels.

Part of the agenda for Copenhagen was to discuss the shock-horror data provided by the University of East Anglia's climate research unit.

All this data was proved to be fraudulent and figures had been tampered with, going back to 1962.

Ms O'Connor accuses Mr Stevenson of calling ``the esteemed thinkers nutters, hysterical, cultist or liars", but that's precisely what the climate research unit provided _ lies.

She goes on to suggest that Mr Stevenson read the Australian Climate Commission's ``highly regarded work and findings".

Again, why bother? Tim Flannery (Australian of the Year 2007) warned in 2008 that Adelaide could run out of water by 2009, and that Perth was going to become a ghost town.

In northern latitudes, London and New York were going to be flooded to the level of eight- storey buildings.

Ms O'Connor, as Minister for Climate Change, represents a discredited and impoverished government and the real message must be read between the lines towards the end of her letter when she says that to avoid the worst effect of global warming, we must ``rethink our economic and social policy structures".

Translated into English, this means that the government wants to increase taxes again and further cut social services and allowances.

_ COL HAYWARD, St Helens.

Flag's meaning

SO, a Canberra university wonk has designed a new Australian flag for us (The Examiner, January 25).

No doubt there are many skilled artists, designers and even professors who could put together a nice composite.

Then there would be the marketing gurus and political scientists who could wear down public support for the current flag with slick TV ads and email campaigns.

Thanks, but no thanks.

The Australian flag is not a throw-together of a Union Jack, Southern Cross and Commonwealth star as its critics would have us believe.

It is our flag. The flag we are all familiar with, which unifies our national solidarity during time of war, triumph and tragedy, is not even an invention of our generation.

It is in fact our inheritance, created and left for us by our Australian forefathers. We should be thankful for it. These debates, deliberately timed annually around Australia Day, can deliver only division and disagreement.

I am not unmoved by the voices which say the flag doesn't represent me.

But my gentle reminder should be our strong agreement: the flag, whatever its colours, symbols and history, is nothing to do with our individual preference, it's about symbolising us as a nation to ourselves and being instantly recognisable abroad.

This is something the flag has done remarkably well over many decades and in every corner of the globe.

_ MICHAEL FERGUSON, MHA, Member for Bass.

Forest fire alarm

NOW that the fire danger has reduced a little, it is time to look to the future.

And what a bleak future it is. The Greens and their NGO allies have attempted to tie up 570,000 hectares of native forest with no thought as to how any fires in this area could be fought.

Now that Gunns has gone (thanks mainly to the Greens), we have less trained people to fight fires and to keep the fire trails open.

Forestry workers are disappearing at a rate of knots so they cannot help and Parks and Wildlife personnel are being reduced due to the mismanagement of the state budget.

In fact, will there be any fire trails if the proposed legislation is passed?

One suspects not. Watch out, Hobart, Mount Wellington is at risk from this legislation.

_ ERIC HOBBS, EGM Data Services, Devonport.

urn:contentItem:7W9B-0K20-YBDY-R4VH-00000-00Doom & gloom2009-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisMXPg. 12Doom & gloom

* ZIMBABWE BUS CRASH CLAIMS 33

At least 33 people were killed and several injured when an overtaking bus hit an oncoming truck on a notorious road about 90km south of the Zimbabwean capital Harare last night.

Most of the dead were on the bus, which overturned three times.

The Harare to Masvingo road is one of the most dangerous in Zimbabwe, with much of the country's infrastructure in disrepair.

* SPAIN, GREECE HIT BY FOREST FIRES

Spain's prime minister has broken off his holiday to inspect the devastation caused by forest fires raging on an island in the Canaries that have forced thousands to flee their homes.

In Greece, firefighters supported by water-dropping planes were battling forest fires in the southern Peloponnese peninsula and northeast region of Kavala today.

The two countries have been among the worst hit by wildfires that have swept across southern Europe in the past two weeks amid sizzling temperatures and fierce winds.

About 500 firefighters, forest rangers and soldiers fought the flames on Spain's small holiday island of La Palma. The fires had destroyed between 1500 and 2000ha of pine forest since they broke out on Saturday.

In Greece, four planes, one helicopter, 11 vehicles and 46 firefighters battled a pine forest fire as strong winds fanned the flames in a hard-to-reach area on the Peloponnese's Menalon mountain, the firefighters' press service said

* THOUSANDS FLEE BLAZES IN CANADA

Firefighters in British Columbia have been struggling to contain some 500 forest fires that have forced the evacuation of 2700 people and left 2300 more ready to leave at a moment's notice.

Wind and a lack of humidity helped revive two blazes today that had been burning for almost two weeks at Terrace Mountain, near the town of Kelowna, 400km east of Vancouver.

The fires, which were estimated yesterday to be affecting about 4600ha, grew significantly overnight, the Vancouver Sun reported.

The danger posed by the rapid progress of the blazes forced firefighters to pause their efforts temporarily, she said, adding that 2700 residents who had returned to their homes two days earlier were ordered to evacuate again yesterday.

Another 2300 residents of the town of Lillooet have been told to be ready to evacuate at a moment's notice.

* IRAQ BOMBINGS KILL EIGHT

Four women and three children were among eight people killed by bombings across Iraq today, security and medical officials said.

In the deadliest attack, a car bomb exploded in a popular market in the centre of the western town of Haditha.

``We received seven killed, four women and three children, and 17 wounded, including women and children,'' Dr Ahmed Hussein from Haditha hospital said.

An Iraqi army captain in Haditha, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, confirmed the toll at seven dead but said more than 20 were injured.

* FOREIGNERS DIE IN CHINA SMASH

Four foreigners were among five people killed when a bus and a car collided in China's remote western Qinghai province, state media said today.

The five, who were all travelling in the car, died at the scene of the accident in the mountainous region, Xinhua news agency said, without revealing the nationalities of the dead.

Police said they would ask local foreign affairs agencies to help confirm their names and nationalities.

The crash happened in Garang, 70km from the provincial capital of Xining, with at least 20 people on the bus injured.

urn:contentItem:5532-BKP1-JD6R-T14Y-00000-00Fuel for an inflationary hellfire2012-03-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisFuel for an inflationary hellfireKaren MaleyABSTRACT

The world's largest hedge fund has warned trillions of central bank stimulus now sloshing around is kindling for a huge inflationary fire that could grow less controllable the longer it is stoked.

FULL TEXT


As markets step up the pressure on Ben Bernanke to pump even more money into the financial system, many are concerned that activist strain of central banking that's swept through the developed world is stoking the fires for an even larger financial bonfire.
In his latest note, John Taylor, chief investment officer of FX Concepts, the world's largest currency hedge fund, points out that the trend had its beginning in 1979 with the Chrysler bailout. At that stage, the US Treasury guaranteed a $1.5 billion loan to the car manufacturer, but in return the US government demanded, and received, $2 billion in concessions from unions, the company, and other stakeholders.
But, Taylor notes, central bank activism took a big step forward when Alan Greenspan took over as the boss of the US central bank. Greenspan reversed the 1987 stockmarket collapse, he rescued Mexico in 1995, South East Asia in 1997 and then went on to save the global banking system which was at risk after the collapse of the speculative hedge fund Long Term Capital in 1998.
Greenspan, of course, had some failures, notably the Russian default in 1998. But overall, Taylor argues, the perceived Greenspan "put" - the idea that the US central bank would slash interest rates and boost liquidity whenever a crisis arose - made investors extremely complacent. "Buy risk, you were safe, was the only way to go".
But Taylor points out that Greenspan's efforts to rescue the global banking system after the LTCM collapse now look like child's play. "The central banks have to pay a lot more for optimism today. Loans aren't enough; now they must give the money away. Printing presses are running flat out... and the developed world monetary base is almost three times higher than it was at the start of 2008."
According to Taylor, "all this money sloshing around is nothing but kindling. This is enough to start one hell of a large inflationary fire, but probably not until we have a deflationary panic first - which will add even more kindling to the pile."
Taylor argues that the progression from the first $1.5 billion Chrysler rescue to today's multi-trillion dollar efforts by central banks in the US, the United Kingdom, Europe and Japan to support financial markets is similar to efforts to suppress forest fires.
Although fire-fighters are able to limit small fires, they now know that the longer they suppress them, the greater the chances of a highly disastrous, totally uncontrollable, conflagration.
When that catastrophe will occur is unpredictable but "by suppressing small fires, the forests approach an unstable state where the dead wood, resulting from the natural cycle of birth and death in the wild, is piled high, ready to explode into flames if the conditions are right."
Taylor argues that central banks in the developed world are following exactly the same approach. "The central banks and other governmental authorities have piled the money so high that bubbles are popping up everywhere."
Inflation may not have hit food prices yet, but Taylor argues that it is certainly hitting other asset prices, which is impoverishing those who do not own these inflating assets.
He also points out that this strategy of inflating asset prices is highly risky. "As those assets are in a bubble, a sharp reversal in price could appear at any time, just like the fire might begin in the forest. With so many bubbles and so much kindling, volatility in price is a sure thing."
It's impossible to accurately predict the timing of these dramatic breakdowns - whether it's a forest fire, an earthquake or a market crash. It's also extremely difficult to contain the damage they wreak.
Taylor notes that fire fighters have now worked out that the best way to control conflagrations is before they start. But, he pleads, "please tell Bernanke!"

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>VIC: EAST VICTORIAN FIRE BURNS THROUGH 27,000 HECTARES</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MELBOURNE, Jan 3 AAP - An out-of-control bushfire is gaining strength and speed in an east Victorian national park after already burning out 27,000 hectares of forest.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Light rains overnight provided little relief for firefighters battling the blaze in the Gippsland Alpine National Park, about 150 kilometres east of Melbourne, which ripped through a further 20,000 hectares overnight after flaring midweek.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Spokeswoman for the Department of Natural Resources and Environment (DNRE) Liz Brown said "It jumped from about seven to 27 hectares overnight."</p><p>Light rains fell for a short while at about 2am (AEDT), "but it's not going to do much good unless it continues for a few days", Ms Brown said.</p><p> She said the fire was gathering speed and force as it burned through thickly vegetated areas where firefighters were unable to set up control lines.</p><p> "It's building up its own head of steam," she said.</p><p> Thirty bulldozers are struggling to cut firebreaks through heavily forested and steep terrain, while 10 aircraft, including waterbombers, and 10 water tankers fight the blaze.</p><p> Victorian Premier Jeff Kennett will visit the scene this morning, inspecting the site of a new fire control headquarters at nearby hamlet Licola.</p><p> The fire has been described as the worst forest fire in Victoria for more than a decade, and is forecast to burn unchecked through 50,000 hectares, taking as much as a fortnight to control.</p><p> believed to have started from a campfire on New Year's Eve.</p><p> The said there was no threat to private land.</p><p> The fire took the state past a 20-year average for the number of hectares burnt, "and we are only halfway through the fire season", the DNRE said in a statement today.</p><p> The cost of containing the fire was expected to be more than $2 million, an estimate which did not include the cost of rehabilitation work, the DNRE said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WRAP - Victorian fires may have been deliberately lit</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Susan Murdoch</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>MELBOURNE, Jan 22</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fires which destroyed four houses in Victoria's north-east overnight, and continue to rage out of control, are believed to have been deliberately lit.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Country Fire Authority (CFA) chief fire officer Russell Rees said three fires began in quick succession, destroying four houses and a shed at Yackandandah, Stanley and in the Indigo Valley.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The origin of these fires are suspicious … and are being investigated by police," Mr Rees told reporters.</p><p>More than 20,000ha has now been burned at Eldorado, and up to 4,000ha was razed in Stanley, with the flames racing through grassland, scrub, plantation pines and box ironbark country.</p><p>However, Mr Rees said given there were 130 houses directly in the path of the fires, the efforts of firefighters and the community had worked well.</p><p>"It's outstanding that the losses were so small," he said.</p><p>By mid afternoon, the Eldorado and Stanley fires had slowed along the frontlines and firefighters were controlling them from the flanks.</p><p>Relief centres have been established at Wodonga, Chiltern, Beechworth, Myrtleford and Bright for residents who have fled their homes.</p><p>Mr Rees said firefighters were working frantically ahead of forecast extreme conditions over the weekend, but he said with conditions so dry after five years of drought, the fires were continuing to burn regardless of the temperature or wind direction.</p><p>"There has been 15 days of solid fires, in my view there is no end in sight," Mr Rees said.</p><p>Meanwhile, exhausted crews in Victoria's north-eastern alpine areas, where lightning strikes started a series of fires earlier this month, were today relieved with reinforcements arriving from around the state.</p><p>A team of forest fire experts from New Zealand had also been deployed to the Gippsland fires near Omeo, which were burning through dense, rugged country.</p><p>The threat to the township of Bright eased overnight and firefighters were able to hold control lines around the blaze, now burning on a 100km front.</p><p>Mr Rees praised the efforts of the CFA and reminded employers that it was crucial volunteers continued to be made available.</p><p>Meanwhile, residents in several streets at Lysterfield in Melbourne's east were today urged to activate their bushfire plans.</p><p>CFA spokesman Peter Philp said the grass and bushland fire remained within containment lines but residents - dressed appropriately in heavy duty clothes - were urged to extinguish any falling embers.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2003</dc:source><dc:source urn:contentItem:57FR-2GB1-JD3N-5209-00000-00States ablaze as fire razes homes Focus turns to emergency spots2013-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4States ablaze as fire razes homes Focus turns to emergency spotsMatt Smith, with AAP

FIREFIGHTERS were last night battling 140 blazes in NSW, but the state escaped the catastrophe that had been feared.

Alarmingly, three young boys, arrested yesterday while on their push bikes, are suspected of starting a fire about 200 metres from homes in Sydney's west in 42 degree heat.

Early in the day there was alarm when a fire broke out in the Lucas Heights nuclear research facility in Sydney's south.

The blaze, in an electrical substation, was doused.

Firefighters are focusing on emergency situations in nine areas of NSW, Victoria and Tasmania as hot, dry and windy conditions envelop southeastern Australia.

The worst-hit area in NSW was in the state's south where temperatures hit the low 40s and with winds of up to 90km/h.

Victoria's CFA will send 20 firefighters and an air crane to help the effort in NSW, allowing its Rural Fire Service crews to move to northern fires.

Across the state more than 1200 firefighters backed by about 350 trucks and 63 aircraft were tackling the fires.

By yesterday afternoon more than 54,000 hectares had burned, with no homes or lives lost.

A cool change was making its way across the state, but similar hot and windy conditions were expected later in the week.

Rural Fire Service Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons said there was still much work to do.

``Right across the state we are seeing fires breaching some of their containment lines, and we've also got fire agencies identifying new fires that are starting up,'' Mr Fitzsimmons told reporters.

The Bureau of Meteorology yesterday confirmed Monday was Australia's hottest day ever, with a national average maximum temperature of 40.33 degrees.

The new record was 0.16 degrees hotter than the previous hottest day -- December 21, 1972.

However the record is likely to last just 24 hours, with yesterday predicted to be even hotter than Monday when final calculations are released this afternoon.

Meanwhile in Tasmania, residents and tourists stranded on the Tasman Peninsula for five days have been led out of the devastating bushfire zone as fire crews continue to battle established and new blazes across the state.

There were no emergency-alert areas in Tasmania last night, but 43 fires were being managed.

Towns and communities remain on high alert around the state as fires continue to burn near Mawbanna in the far northwest, in the Upper Derwent Valley, north of Hobart, and near Bicheno on the east coast.

Victorian crews arrived in Hobart to help search burnt out properties in the Dunalley region for the bodies of people police fear may have perished in the fires.

Tasmania Police assistant commissioner Donna Adams said yesterday there were no confirmed deaths but about 100 people were unaccounted for.

NT

Scores of guests yesterday evacuated the Kings Canyon Resort in central Australia, 300km from Alice Springs, as a bushfire burned through the site.

QUEENSLAND

Eight bushfires burning across Queensland with fire authorities on high alert with extremely hot weather about to hit the state.

NSW

More than 1200 firefighters backed by about 350 trucks and 63 aircraft were tackling fires across the state.

By yesterday afternoon more than 54,000ha had burned, with 130 fires burning, 40 of them uncontained.

The major fires were at Deans Gap, near Nowra, with 15ha burning, and Tarcutta, near Wagga, with 500ha in flames. Victorian firefighters were expected to help fight a massive blaze at Kybeyan, near Cooma.

ACT

A forest fire is burning in the ACT's south in Namadgi National Park. It is under control but worse conditions are forecast.

SOUTH AUSTRALIA

A string of bushfires continue to burn across northern South Australia, most in remote areas.

TASMANIA

Fires have destroyed at least 128 homes, mainly on the Tasman Peninsula. The damage to private property is estimated to be at least $42 million, but that figure is set to rise dramatically.

Forty fires continue to burn, with bushfire emergency warning issued yesterday for Montumana in the northwest.

VICTORIA

At least two homes lost in Snake Gully, about 30km from Ballarat, with dozens more houses under threat.

At Kentbruck, in the southwest, 9000ha has burned. A wind change late yesterday was expected to push it towards Dartmoor.

Severe danger continues in the northwest.

A grassfire burned 8ha at Sunbury.

urn:contentItem:47RT-2W40-015H-008M-00000-00<published>2003-01-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 11</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Fires out of control</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIRES which destroyed four houses in Victoria's northeast overnight, and continue to rage out of control, are believed to have been deliberately lit.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Country Fire Authority chief fire officer Russell Rees said three fires began in quick succession, destroying four houses and a shed at Yackandandah, Stanley and in the Indigo Valley.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The origins of these fires are suspicious and are being investigated by police," Mr Rees said.</p><p>NSW firefighters yesterday took advantage of milder weather conditions to try to contain 30 blazes still burning out of control.</p><p>Fires were still burning around the ACT, Snowy Mountains, Yass, Armidale, Wyong and Gosford areas.</p><p>In Tasmania, firefighters contained a blaze which destroyed four houses in the State's south on Tuesday. But nine fires continued to burn out of control in timber country.</p><p>In Melbourne, Mr Rees said 20,000ha had now been burned at Eldorado and up to 4000ha razed at Stanley, with the flames racing through grassland, scrub, plantation pines and box ironbark country.</p><p>Mr Rees said given there were 130 houses directly in the path of the fires, the efforts of firefighters and the community had worked well.</p><p>"It's outstanding that the losses were so small," he said.</p><p>By mid afternoon, the Eldorado and Stanley fires had slowed along the frontlines and firefighters were controlling them from the flanks.</p><p>Relief centres have been established at Wodonga, Chiltern, Beechworth, Myrtleford and Bright for residents who have fled their homes.</p><p>Mr Rees said firefighters were working frantically ahead of forecast extreme conditions over the weekend, but he said with conditions so dry after five years of drought, the fires were continuing to burn regardless of the temperature or wind.</p><p>"There has been 15 days of solid fires, in my view there is no end in sight," Mr Rees said.</p><p>A team of forest fire experts from New Zealand had now been deployed to the Gippsland fires near Omeo, which were burning through dense, rugged country.</p><p>The threat to Bright eased overnight and firefighters were able to hold control lines around the blaze, now burning on a 100km front.</p><p>Mr Rees praised the efforts of the CFA and reminded employers that it was crucial volunteers continued to be made available.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
