urn:contentItem:57FW-NKP1-F0JP-W444-00000-00Sweating over a cool break Nation's southeast corner a blazing inferno2013-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Sweating over a cool break Nation's southeast corner a blazing infernoStaff reporters, AAP, Canberra

FIREFIGHTERS are focusing on emergencies in nine areas of NSW, Victoria and Tasmania as hot, dry and windy conditions envelop southeastern Australia.

With 140 fires burning across NSW, the worst-hit area was in the state's south where temperatures hit the low 40s and winds of up to 90km/h swept through the southern ranges.

At Tarcutta, near Wagga Wagga, 18 tankers and two helicopters were battling a bushfire that had broken northern containment lines and closed the Hume Highway.

The fire is understood to have damaged hay and machinery sheds, and locals had taken refuge at the Tarcutta RSL and Citizens Club.

Eva Toth, who owns the Tarcutta Halfway Motor Inn, ran between her car and office, packing her computer and insurance paperwork.

``It's absolutely a burning scorcher,'' she said. ``It's like someone put the hairdryer on your face.''

Across the state more than 1200 firefighters, 350 trucks and 63 aircraft were tackling the fires.

By yesterday afternoon more than 54,000ha had burned, with no homes or lives lost.

Other areas of concern included Sand Hills near Bungendore, Range Rd in the Upper Lachlan area, Deans Gap in the Shoalhaven area near Nowra, the Bega Valley, Yarrabin east of Cooma, and Bogan Gate near Parkes in the state's central west.

A cool change was making its way across the state but similarly hot and windy conditions were expected later in the week.

Rural Fire Service Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons said there was still much work to do.

``Right across the state we are seeing fires breaching some of their containment lines, and we've also got fire agencies identifying new fires,'' Mr Fitzsimmons told reporters.

``We've got a lot of daylight left and a lot of night-time left under these conditions. The front that's moving through NSW is not expected to pass through some of our worst areas until much later tonight.''

Meanwhile, in Tasmania - which has endured almost a week of intense and damaging fires - police had yet to find any bodies in 550 homes searched in the state's south.

A second round of more comprehensive searches is expected to begin in the next two days with a contingent of Victorian police arriving to look for around 100 people still unaccounted for.

At 5pm yesterday there were no emergency-alert areas in Tasmania, but 43 fires were being managed, focusing on Forcett and Lake Repulse in the south, and Holwell, Montumanna and Mathinna in the north.

NATIONAL BUSHFIRE THREAT

NEW SOUTH WALES

Dozens of homes under threat as NSW firefighters battle 135

blazes in 40C-plus temperatures and "catastrophic" conditions.

The worst fires were in the south, near Cooma, Nowra, Bega and

Wagga.

Although 40 fires remained uncontained, by mid-afternoon there

had been no reports of loss of life or homes.

Other "emergency" alerts were at Oura, Mates Gully and

Munyabla, near Wagga, and Narrandera, southwest of Wagga.

Up to 90 per cent of NSW was in severe danger, with conditions

officially described as catastrophic in the Illawarra, Shoalhaven and

Southern Ranges.

A total fire ban is in place across NSW.

TASMANIA

A bushfire emergency warning has been issued for Kellevie and

Bream Creek in the southeast and Mathinna in the northeast.

The Tasman Peninsula blaze is threatening the small bayside

towns of Eaglehawk Neck, Pirates Bay and Doo Town.

About 40 bushfires continue to burn across the state.

More than 550 houses have been searched and no bodies found

VICTORIA

An 8ha grassfire has burnt the fences of several Sunbury homes

in Melbourne's northwest.

The Kentbruck fire in Victoria's southwest continues to burn,

threatening the commnuity of Drik Drik, while authorities are on alert

for severe fi re conditions in the state's north.

SOUTH AUSTRALIA

A string of bushfires continue to burn across northern South

Australia but are not causing concern.

QUEENSLAND

Eight bushfires are burning across Queensland but none are

posing a threat to property.

NORTHERN TERRITORY

A bushfire in central Australia forced guests at the Kings Canyon

Resort, about 300km southwest of Alice Springs, to evacuate.

ACT

A forest fire is burning in the ACTs south.

A total fire ban has been declared.

WA

WA has so far avoided bushfires.

FIRE FIGHTERS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>PAUL KAUZLARIC, ED FEATHERSTON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FOREST fire fighters in East Gippsland have been honing their skills in preparation for a tough fire season throughout the State.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Six brigades from Australian Paper Plantations Pty Ltd were involved in a competition last week at the Willung forest airstrip near Rosedale to see how fast, skilful and efficient their crews could be in simulated emergency situations.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> To test the team's overall fire preparedness and ability to tackle all firefighting tasks, three members of each team were told only hours earlier what event they would be in.</p><p>Knowledge, skill and speed were put to the test in events which included laying foam firebreaks, refilling tankers from a dam, extinguishing tree-top "stag" blazes, clearing away obstacles from tracks, and chainsawing logs from the path of fire trucks.</p><p> The Flynn Creek plantation team, trained by forester Rob Hescock, won three of the five events to notch its fourth consecutive annual Inter Tree Farm Fire Crew Competition shield win.</p><p> Winning team members in each event were awarded $100, with their cheques presented by Police and Emergency Services Minister Bill McGrath.</p><p> Mr McGrath said fire outbreaks would occur, but with fire preparation and suppression work and early strike power the damage could be restricted.</p><p> There was a demonstration of helicopter fire bombing by Amcor's chartered $600,000-plus helicopter.</p><p> Pilot Liz Whiley lifted more than 450 litres of a foam-water mix with each lift, dumping it to control a bonfire in three drops.</p><p> Long service awards were presented to Les Sands (30 years), Douglas Membrey (25) and Alan Sawyer (25).</p><p> The demonstration day included the annual CFA inspection of the six brigades, with the CFA's regional officer Euan Ferguson and risk management director John Nicholson involved.</p><p> This year's competition was staged when the state faces what experts say may be one of its worst bushfire seasons.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4D9M-0270-015H-91VG-00000-00<published>2004-09-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 18</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>North Korean blast causes jitters</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A HUGE explosion that rocked North Korea three days ago sparked concern yesterday but South Korean and US officials said it was unlikely to have been a nuclear weapons test despite a report the blast produced a mushroom cloud.</p><p nitf:lede="true">South Korea's Yonhap news agency said the blast on Thursday in Ryanggang province, in the north-east near the border with China appeared much bigger than a train explosion that killed at least 170 people in April.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The New York Times reported yesterday that the Bush administration had received recent intelligence reports that some experts believed could indicate North Korea was preparing to conduct its first nuclear weapons test explosion.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Reuters</p></bodyText></section><p>But in Washington, US officials said there was no definitive explanation yet, although the blast did not appear to be nuclear.</p><p>"We've got no indication that anything of the sort has happened. We believe these reports to be completely unfounded," said a State Department official.</p><p>"People are pretty sure it's not a mushroom cloud and not a test of any kind."</p><p>Yonhap said a mushroom cloud up to 4km in diameter was seen after the blast in an area near missile bases.</p><p>South Korean Unification Minister Chung Dong-young also played down an atomic link, telling reporters after a National Security Council meeting that Seoul's assessment so far was the explosion was unlikely to have been part of the communist North's nuclear arms ambitions.</p><p>"There are some foreign media reporting such possibilities, but we are judging at the moment the explosion is unrelated to such reports," Yonhap quoted him as saying.</p><p>South Korea's weather service said no earth tremors had been detected.</p><p>North Korea has said nothing so far about a blast, but often reports on events long after they happen.</p><p>Japan said it was checking the reports.</p><p>There was no immediate reaction from North Korea's big neighbour and main ally, China.</p><p>Thursday was the 56th anniversary of North Korea's founding. The reclusive communist state often stages extravaganzas and big events to mark important anniversaries.</p><p>The reports surfaced as South Korea, Japan, China, Russia and the United States were seeking to persuade North Korea to return to the negotiating table to discuss its nuclear weapons ambitions.</p><p>Yonhap quoted one source as saying Thursday's reported mushroom cloud could have been caused by a forest fire. Other possibilities include a failed missile engine test, a high-explosives test as a precursor to a nuclear blast or an industrial accident.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>'BLUE' MOON IS SHINING OUR WAY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>COKLEY J</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KEYWORD-HIT</p><p nitf:lede="true">"Blue'</p><p nitf:lede="true">moon is</p><p nitf:lede="true">shining</p><p nitf:lede="true">our way</p><p nitf:lede="true">]By science writer</p><p nitf:lede="true">JOHN COKLEY T HE expression ""once in a blue moon" will come true</p><p nitf:lede="true">for Queenslanders next Saturday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A ""blue moon" refers to the occurrence of two full moons in the</p><p nitf:lede="true">same calendar month _ exactly what happens on Saturday at 10.38pm.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>The first of the pair happened at 4.54am on October 1.</p><p>The event is as rare as the traditional expression makes out,</p><p>because although there were two within two months in 1991, the next one</p><p>is not expected until 1996.</p><p>And these October moons have further significance, both for</p><p>astronomers and for observant Chinese.</p><p>That's because the first of our two full moons this month marked</p><p>the celebration of the Moon goddess Hong O, the northern hemisphere's</p><p>mid-autumn moon festival.</p><p>Brisbane planetarium curator Jeff Ryder said yesterday the last</p><p>occurrence of blue moons here stood out because there were two within</p><p>two months _ in January and March.</p><p>""But the incidence of so-called ""blue" moons has nothing to do</p><p>with the colour blue . . . except you see the moon coloured blue about</p><p>as often as you see two full moons in a month."</p><p>In the same way as moons sometimes appear orange or red due to</p><p>particles in the atmosphere (often seen at Harvest Moon) the moon could</p><p>appear blue through a haze of fine ash such as might be caused by a</p><p>forest fire or volcanic eruption.</p><p>The real reason for a blue moon is the lunar month spans 29 1/2</p><p>days and the coincidence of two full moons in a 30-day month is</p><p>extremely rare: the last one happened in April 1961 and the next is not</p><p>expected until November 2001.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P6W-5290-TXN5-R203-00000-00Bark of the lapdog2006-04-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESLeadersPg. 10Bark of the lapdogBizarre and tasteless cartoon war

The late Adam Malik, long Indonesia's foreign minister and later vice-president, was called the "kancil" after the mousedeer which, in his country's folktales, uses cunning and humour against bigger predators. In one story Mr Malik's admirers used to tell - not one found in illustrated children's books - the mousedeer evades a tiger by running into a hollow log. The tiger gets its head trapped, whereupon the kancil exits the other end of the log and mounts the tiger from behind. Indonesians enjoy a ribald animal yarn as much as anyone.

But what to make of the recent dog-mounts-dog cartoons published in two newspapers? First, the Indonesian popular tabloid Rakyat Merdeka shows John Howard and Alexander Downer as humping dingoes, somehow related to an alleged Australian wish to take over Papua. Then The Weekend Australian, a newspaper published by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, responds with a cartoon showing the Indonesian President, Bambang Susilo Yudhoyono, in formal black headcap, as a dog mounting a four-legged Papuan with a bone in his nose. "No offence intended" was the caption.

Actually, the cartoon could hardly be calculated to offend more. The Rakyat Merdeka drawing was not particularly funny or on-target, aside from being tasteless, so was easy for its targets to shrug off. The Murdoch newspaper's cartoon is consciously more offensive, since the dog is regarded as a particularly unclean animal by Indonesia's Muslims. It is hard to think of any other world leader being depicted the same way as the cartoon did Mr Yudhoyono. Indeed, by sharp contrast, the same newspaper had just set what may be record levels of sycophancy in its coverage of visits by Condoleezza Rice, Tony Blair and Wen Jiabao. When another of its cartoonists depicted the former president Soeharto as an orang-utang swinging nonchalantly through the jungles, during the 1997 forest-fire haze and economic crisis, its editors were soon on a plane to grovel in Jakarta. See-sawing between adulation and reckless offence hardly reflects well on editorial judgement. Sentiment in the Muslim world is inflamed enough. It's a time to do what you do with rutting dogs: bring out the hose.

Meanwhile, the failings of Indonesia's rule in Papua are apparent enough. They go back many years before Mr Yudhoyono became President, and he seems willing to break with the past as he did in Aceh. Though not happy about the cartoon, he seems willing to let it pass and is damping down any movement among his officials to react on his behalf. As Adam Malik used to say: the dogs may bark, the caravan moves on.

urn:contentItem:7VHS-Y010-YBDY-R3P6-00000-00Doom & gloom2009-04-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisMXPg. 10Doom & gloom

MUM'S FAECES BABY-KILLING BID

A mother injected her one-year-old son with his own excrement in a bizarre bid to kill him, a German court has been told.

Doctors had been baffled by baby Carlos's acute fever and constant blood poisoning after his mum took him to a hospital in Berlin, Germany.

But when the tot got worse after four weeks of treatment they began to suspect his 39-year-old mother, Elisabeth Kuefer, and searched her handbag.

Inside they found a collection of syringes loaded with the youngster's own faeces, a Berlin court heard.

Judges adjourned the case for psychiatric reports on the mum, who is said to be suffering from Munchhausen-Syndrome - a psychiatric disorder in which people feign illness to attract sympathy.

ARRESTS MADE IN BODY PARTS CASE

UK police have made two arrests in connection with the discovery of a man's body parts strewn across the countryside.

The case has challenged detectives and prompted repeated appeals for witnesses.

The man's legs, arms and head have been found hidden near roads and in fields in the English counties of Hertfordshire and Leicestershire in recent weeks.

The suspects, aged in their 20s and 30s, were both arrested in London on Tuesday.

SOLDIERS KILLED BATTLING BLAZE

Fourteen soldiers have been killed while trying to put out a forest fire in a village in Nepal's mountainous northeast.

They were trying to stop the fire from reaching a hospital but some became trapped when the wind changed direction.

The bodies have not yet been identified.

SHEIK INVOLVED IN TORTURE VIDEO

The United Arab Emirates has acknowledged a member of its ruling family is the man seen in videotapes torturing another man with a cattle prod and setting his genitals on fire, an American news network reports.

The torture allegations against Sheik Issa bin Zayed Al Nahyan surfaced a year ago when Texas businessman Bassem Nabulsi, a former business associate and adviser to the sheik, filed a lawsuit against him in the US and revealed still images from one of the videos.

Nabulsi is not the man being tortured in the video. The victim is believed to be a man who the sheik felt had overcharged him in a grain deal, Nabulsi's lawyers say.

CORNERED TIGER REBELS FIGHT ON

Sri Lanka's cornered Tiger rebels have put up stiff resistance despite calls for their surrender, the military says, as the UN ordered an urgent humanitarian mission to the region.

The army says the guerrillas are confined to a mere 10-12sq km of territory on the northeast coast, where thousands of civilians are trapped by the fighting.

As international concern mounts for the safety of between 15,000 and 20,000 civilians, UN secretary-general Ban Ki-moon ordered a humanitarian team to northern Sri Lanka.

ISRAEL ACCUSED OF ARMY COVER-UP

Human Rights Watch claimed the Israeli army's investigation of troop conduct during its war on Gaza appeared to be an attempt to cover up ``violations of the laws of war''.

The army defended its conduct during the massive 22-day offensive against the Hamas rulers of Gaza in December and January, saying five military probes found its forces ``operated in accordance with international law''.

But Joe Stork, of Human Rights Watch, said: ``The conclusions are an apparent attempt to mask violations.''

urn:contentItem:44JK-P5K0-0198-42JT-00000-00<published>2000-07-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 5</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>VOLUNTEERS LINING UP TO JOIN THE SERVICE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Eleanor Miller</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MORPHETT VALE CFS While some CFS units are desperate for recruits, a local unit just has too applicants. Eleanor Miller reports:</p><p nitf:lede="true"> THE MORPHETT Vale Country Fire Service (CFS) - the busiest in SA - is defying the State trend with about 10 people on its waiting list.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> As other CFS units are desperately needing volunteer recruits, the southern suburbs brigade is having to turn away would-be firefighters.</p><p>Morphett Vale captain Phill McDonough last week was at a loss to explain the popularity of the local brigade.</p><p> "I can't tell you why that is - other areas are desperately needing members," Mr McDonough said.</p><p> It's just as well the unit is so popular as recently released figures show the Morphett Vale brigade attended the most callouts in SA last year.</p><p> The brigade attended a total of 338 incidents, tallying up an estimated 3852 hours for all its volunteers on callouts.</p><p> Incidents ranged from building and rubbish fires to vehicle accidents, faulty alarms, a flood and even rescuing a cat stuck up a tree. The brigade comprises 40 unpaid members - including, usually, four women.</p><p> The average age of members is 32.</p><p> "We use the talents from with in the brigade, we need people who don't just think within the square," Mr McDonough said.</p><p> Training takes place for about three hours on Monday nights and members were often called out to fires up to five times a week.</p><p> "Personally, I have attended about two-thirds of the fires (in the past year)," he said.</p><p> "Some people will attend two-thirds. Others will attend about half.</p><p> We try to select the appropriate people to go to the appropriate jobs."</p><p> Mr McDonough said the most difficult fires he had been called to included a forest fire at Heathfield and "severe" vehicle accidents.</p><p> "Some people react in different ways (but) after a while you get a little bit de-sensitised."</p><p> Captain McDonough said the CFS tended to select volunteers who were family orientated and community-minded.</p><p> "Some of the things you get out of (fire fighting) are camaraderie .</p><p> . . and a sense of achievement for service to the community," he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">ADLMES-MST0007260005007467</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">MESSENGER-SOUTHLTD</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:44JK-P5K0-0198-42JT-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">244806</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-21</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="344"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>Messenger - urn:contentItem:46V3-02X0-015H-J1JG-00000-00<published>2002-09-20T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:13Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Up to the task</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>by JOANNE McCARTHY</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WYONG Rural Fire Service deputy controller Shane Geerin was checking a hazard reduction area in early August when he took a phone call  America needed him.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The next day he was on a plane headed for Oregon and six weeks of wildfire-fighting, US-style.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The aviation operations specialist joined a team of 80 firefighters to deal with an out-of-control forest fire that took nine hours to drive around.</p><p>It was just one of many fires that have devastated at least four American states this summer.</p><p>Mr Geerin had 19 helicopters at his disposal  including four of the Elvis-style choppers [Erickson Air-Cranes] that dazzled Australian firefighters during the Christmas holiday bushfires.</p><p>"They've got the toys and they've got the money," Mr Geerin said after arriving home on Monday. "They do things on a grand scale over there."</p><p>While the Americans had the hardware, the Australians had world-class systems, particularly in the area of fire safety, he said.</p><p>"We provided comment on their systems and a fresh look on how they do things. I got a lot of satisfaction from knowing we are up to the task."</p><p>Fighting fires in conifer forests was "pretty much the same" as fighting eucalyptus bushfires, he said.</p><p>"It's the same sort of work. The vegetation was different but the job was the same."</p><p>The Oregon fire cost $138 million to beat. Nearly 7000 firefighters fought the blaze over several months.</p><p>"It was awesome, a real experience. The infrastructure they've got is just amazing."</p><p>Standard issue gear for the Australians included numerous full sets of protective clothing, safety goggles and helmets, head lamps with "boxes of batteries", flight helmets and suits, a fire shelter in case they were caught in a fire, a tent and sleeping bag and "so much other stuff I've forgotten half of it".</p><p>"We gave it back. We couldn't fit it in to bring home there was so much of it."</p><p>If cricket catches on in America, the four Australian Rural Fire Service officers at the Biscuit fire  named after the Biscuit River that ran through the Oregon forest  will claim the credit for it.</p><p>"They loved it. They had a ball. We'd play cricket in our downtime every day and at the morning briefings we'd update the state of play.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5GXJ-HCH1-F0NT-H4VN-00000-00 Just because you may not have seen a drone overhead doesn't mean it hasn't seen you.2015-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexis Just because you may not have seen a drone overhead doesn't mean it hasn't seen you.StartUpSmartABSTRACT

 Just because you may not have seen a drone overhead doesn't mean it hasn't seen you.

FULL TEXT

 Just because you may not have seen a drone overhead doesn't mean it hasn't seen you. And, as was demonstrated by the killing of two British jihadis in Syria recently, these unmanned aerial vehicles are increasingly deployed by the West as frontline weapons of war.

Drones are set to become a defining feature of this century. Thousands are already in operation in most developed countries worldwide - and that is likely to grow to hundreds of thousands as drones of different shapes and sizes are deployed by the media, emergency services, scientists, farmers, sports enthusiasts, hobbyists, photographers, the armed forces and government agencies.

Eventually commercial uses will dwarf all others. Amazon promises to deliver purchases within 30 minutes via delivery drones. Domino's Pizza has staged hot pizza drone delivery. More than 20 industries are approved to fly commercial drones in the US alone, and developing countries are following suit.

The question is, is this boom in drones moving faster than the law? How to fit such a proliferation of drones into the current regulations? The answers will need to be written into national and international laws quickly in order to govern an increasingly busy airspace. Many existing laws may need to be tweaked, including those governing cyber-security, stalking, privacy and human rights legislation, insurance, contract and commercial law, even the laws of war.

There have after all been numerous suspect or dangerous uses of drones already. For example, illegal flights over seven nuclear plants across France, disruption to   US forest fire-fighting, and seven   near-misses at airports in the UK. In the US several landowners have   shot them down, leading to court cases that pit claims of trespass and the right to privacy against criminal damage.

Piecemeal legal changes not enough

French legislators responded swiftly with a police order to the first balloon flights by the Montgolfier Brothers in 1784 by prohibiting all flights over Paris without prior authorisation. In the same way sovereign states ought to define precisely how and when they will permit drone flights over their territory. So far legal development to govern drone use has been very piecemeal; most countries have done nothing yet.

Again, it was France that was first to introduce dedicated legislation governing drones through a decree in 2012 bringing drones within its civil aviation regulations. Drones are allowed to fly between 50-150 metres from the ground and there are penalties up to five years in prison and fines of 75,000 euros for unlawful use of a drone.

Also in 2012, the US congress passed the Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) Modernisation and Reform Act which required the   integration of civil drones into national airspace by the end of September 2015.

The Italian Civil Aviation Authority issued commercial drone regulations in April 2014. The law vaguely requires the operators to comply with data-protection laws and hold insurance. In the meantime, controversial Italian surveillance firm Hacking Team is already developing drones capable of   delivering spyware to computers and smartphones, infecting them via Wi-Fi.

However, the UK has struggled with fitting drones into its legal framework as neither the Civil Aviation Act nor the Air Navigation Order provide a good fit. The Department for Transport recently announced plans to introduce fines of up to £2,500 for flying drones in built-up areas. Some clarity is provided by the CAA's   Unmanned Aircraft System Operations in UK Airspace Guidance, which requires drone pilots to maintain direct line of sight with drones and limits their altitude to a maximum 120 metres. Small drones must avoid and give way to manned aircraft at all times.

Delivery by drone is already a happening in Switzerland. Jean-Christophe Bott/EPA

Flying in the face of the law

The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) plans to introduce policies to regulate civilian drone flight by 2028 worldwide. The EU and US have signed a formal agreement to cooperate on integrating drones into civil air traffic management. But consensus is notoriously difficult in international regulation - it could take decades to achieve a global agreement.

The last international civil air treaty of note is the 1944 Chicago convention. This impressive treaty created the standards for the   common use of airspace between nations. For example, that every nation has sovereignty over its airspace and that no aircraft operated by the state (such as military or police) will fly over other states without authorisation. It also required nations air regulations to be obeyed and required aircraft to be registered and display their registration marks.

For drones, however, it's not clear what types and sizes of drones are required to be registered and display their nationality. There are drones the size of small birds or even coins that can fly across national borders in near-invisibility, upsetting these egalitarian rules. It's vital these issues are comprehensively dealt with quickly in a new treaty, in the same spirit of egalitarianism as at Chicago in 1944.

Dronefare versus Lawfare

For many, drones are typified by their use for military operations in Afghanistan and Iraq. The US is reported to have up to 7,000 drones in Afghanistan, with the main source of funding for developing modern drone technology coming from the military.

Successive US governments' policies of conducting drone assassinations will perhaps go down as one of the most egregious use of air power in human history, with thousands of lives lost in an amorphous conflict against vaguely-defined al-Qaeda and ISIS "affiliates". The only legitimisation in most cases appears to be White House's early morning bureaucratic meetings.

The American Civil Liberties Union has correctly addressed this, stating: "The targeted killing program itself is not just unlawful but dangerous ... it is dangerous to characterise the entire planet as a battlefield." A recent RAF strike was the first targeted   UK drone attack on a British citizen. However, UK armed Reaper drones have accounted for   up to a third of the 100 airstrikes) in Iraq alone as at January 2015.

Lethal drone technology is going to be available to nearly all countries in a very short time. The possibility that even a few dozen states might follow the path beaten by the US is really a scary proposition - as what goes around may fly around.

Gbenga Oduntan, Senior Lecturer in International Commercial Law, University of Kent

This article was originally published on The Conversation. Read the   original article.

urn:contentItem:7VHS-Y010-YBDY-R3SY-00000-00DOOM & GLOOM2009-04-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 9DOOM & GLOOM

MUM USED FAECES IN BABY-KILL BID

A mother injected her one-year-old son with his own excrement in a bizarre bid to kill him, a German court has been told.

Doctors had been baffled by baby Carlos's acute fever and constant blood poisoning after his mum took him to a hospital in Berlin, Germany.

But when the tot got worse after four weeks of treatment they began to suspect his 39-year-old mother, Elisabeth Kuefer, and searched her handbag.

Inside they found a collection of syringes loaded with the youngster's own faeces, a Berlin court heard.

Judges adjourned the case for psychiatric reports on the mum, who is said to be suffering from Munchhausen-Syndrome a psychiatric disorder in which people feign illness to attract sympathy.

ARRESTS MADE IN BODY PARTS CASE

UK police have made two arrests in connection with the discovery of a man's body parts strewn across the countryside.

The case has challenged detectives and prompted repeated appeals for witnesses.

The man's legs, arms and head have been found hidden near roads and in fields in the English counties of Hertfordshire and Leicestershire in recent weeks.

The suspects, aged in their 20s and 30s, were both arrested in London on Tuesday.

SOLDIERS KILLED BATTLING BLAZE

Fourteen soldiers have been killed while trying to put out a forest fire in a village in Nepal's mountainous northeast.

They were trying to stop the fire from reaching a hospital but some became trapped when the wind changed direction.

The bodies have not yet been identified.

SHEIK INVOLVED IN TORTURE VIDEO

The United Arab Emirates has acknowledged a member of its ruling family is the man seen in videotapes torturing another man with a cattle prod and setting his genitals on fire, an American news network reports.

The torture allegations against Sheik Issa bin Zayed Al Nahyan surfaced a year ago when Texas businessman Bassem Nabulsi, a former business associate and adviser to the sheik, filed a lawsuit against him in the US and revealed still images from one of the videos.

Nabulsi is not the man being tortured in the video. The victim is believed to be a man who the sheik felt had overcharged him in a grain deal, Nabulsi's lawyers say.

CORNERED TIGER REBELS FIGHT ON

Sri Lanka's cornered Tiger rebels have put up stiff resistance despite calls for their surrender, the military says, as the UN ordered an urgent humanitarian mission to the region.

The army says the guerrillas are confined to a mere 10-12sq km of territory on the northeast coast, where thousands of civilians are trapped by the fighting.

As international concern mounts for the safety of between 15,000 and 20,000 civilians, UN secretary-general Ban Ki-moon ordered a humanitarian team to northern Sri Lanka.

ISRAEL ACCUSED OF ARMY COVER-UP

Human Rights Watch claimed the Israeli army's investigation of troop conduct during its war on Gaza appeared to be an attempt to cover up ``violations of the laws of war''.

The army defended its conduct during the massive 22-day offensive against the Hamas rulers of Gaza in December and January, saying five military probes found its forces ``operated in accordance with international law''.

But Joe Stork, of Human Rights Watch, said: ``The conclusions are an apparent attempt to mask violations.''

urn:contentItem:573Y-5C81-F0J6-J242-00000-00Weathering the butterfly effect2012-11-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMBooksPg. 36Weathering the butterfly effectFictionReview by Don Anderson

FLIGHT BEHAVIOUR

Barbara Kingsolver

Faber, 448pp, $32.99

Tiny wingbeats trigger dissenting reactions in a small US town in the grip of climate change.

Barbara Kingsolver came to international fame with her best-selling 1998 novel, The Poisonwood Bible, which achieved the distinctions of being selected for Oprah Winfrey's Book Club and nominated for the Pulitzer Prize. It will come as no surprise if Flight Behaviour receives comparable notice.

Though it may, within Kingsolver's home country, the US, prove socially divisive. If Richard Heinberg, the author of Power Down and a recent visitor to Sydney for the Festival of Dangerous Ideas is to be believed, "Republican candidates think climate change is a hoax", then Kingsolver's novel will not appeal to about 50 per cent of Americans. For Flight Behaviour is not only a novel with climate change at the heart of its drama, but also a novel of which the drama of climate change is close to its author's proselytising heart. Americans have given the world proselytising novelists since Harriet Beecher Stowe's Uncle Tom's Cabin caught Abraham Lincoln's eye.

Australia, a nation not without its climate sceptics, rates a mention from Kingsolver's scientist, Dr Ovid Byron. "Deserts on fire. In New Mexico we are seeing the inferno. Texas is worse. Australia is unimaginably worse, a lot of the continent is in permanent drought." The novel's marvellously misnamed heroine, Dellarobia Turnbow, who dropped out of college when pregnant at 17, thinks of her husband as she well might of certain Australian politicians: "She balked, knowing his wariness of people who wanted to save trees for trees' sake. An easy want, when they weren't your trees, or your foreclosure."

Flight Behaviour is set in rural Tennessee, among the more-or-less dirt poor, though they are soon mud poor due to an extended period of unseasonal rain. They may be socially and educationally deprived, but they have home computers and YouTube, which are very useful for the novel's resolution. It is as if the Bundren family from Faulkner's As I Lay Dying (1930) travelled against all odds, including flood, to get to Jefferson so that Vardaman could have a personal computer.

A reader might be excused for thinking, at the novel's inception, that she had stumbled into a work of magical realism, sort of Gabriel Garcia Marquez gone north to the Appalachians. Dellarobia, having turned her back on the family shack and gone up the hill to pursue an illicit carnal encounter, is overwhelmed to perceive, or rather to misinterpret, what she takes to be a forest fire, but which is in fact millions of Monarch butterflies glowing "like a lake of fire". Climate change has caused their migration pattern to be thrown out of kilter.

After the butterflies come the scientists, led Dr Byron, who points out that the butterflies have been driven by pollution from their customary Mexican winter grounds and now face extinction due to northern hemisphere temperatures. No less threatening is the fact that Dellarobia's father-in-law, Bear, has sold their land to loggers.

As Feathertown, Tennessee, near which the Turnbows live, is in Bible-belt territory, the butterfly manifestation is dubbed by some locals a "miracle", a miracle that they are prepared to exploit under the banner of tourism. All these threads make Flight Behaviour an often hilarious novel, less sober but no less serious than it might have been had it been merely social-consciousness tract.

For all that, Flight Behaviour is concerned with the universal catastrophe of climate change; it is also concerned, essentially, with the local, where, as local paediatrician William Carlos Williams observed, "all things reside". Kingsolver accesses the local through a family and its friends. Isn't that what the novel, from Mansfield Park to The Corrections has always done, and done better than any non-fiction study?

While Byron may be the book's "mind" ("We are seeing a bizarre alteration of a previously stable pattern. A continental ecosystem breaking down ... Climate change has disrupted this system.") Dellarobia is its conscience ("Maybe her father was lucky to die young with his pride of craftsmanship intact ... Realistically it probably wasn't slave children, but there had to be armies of factory workers making this slapdash stuff ... A worldwide entrapment of bottom feeders.")

It is to Kingsolver's credit that she declines to bring mind and conscience together in any easy amatory connection, though she does appear to have been tempted. Her conclusion is far more dramatic, far more satisfying.

The butterfly manifestation is dubbed by some locals, Bear's wife included, a "miracle", a miracle that they are prepared to exploit under the banner of tourism. All these threads make Flight Behaviour an often hilarious novel, a less sober but no less serious text than it might have been had it been merely social-consciousness tract.

For all that Flight Behaviour is concerned with the universal catastrophe of climate change, it is also concerned essentially with the local where, as local pediatrician William Carlos Williams observed, "all things reside". Kingsolver accesses the local through a family and its friends. Isn't that what the novel, from Mansfield Park to The Corrections has always done, and done better than any non-fictional study?

While Ovid Byron may be the book's "mind" ("We are seeing a bizarre alteration of a previously stable pattern. A continental ecosystem breaking down ... Climate change has disrupted this system.") Dellarobia is its conscience ("Maybe her father was lucky to die young with his pride of craftsmanship intact ... Realistically it probably wasn't slave children, but there had to be armies of factory workers making this slap-dash stuff... A worldwide entrapment of bottom feeders.") It is to Barbara Kingsolver's credit that she declines to bring mind and conscience together in any easy amatory connection, though she does appear to have been tempted. Her conclusion is far more dramatic, far more satisfying.

urn:contentItem:7VH0-HJX1-2RYX-10Y6-00000-00NO CHANCE Fatal fire flaws to be exposed2009-04-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1NO CHANCE Fatal fire flaws to be exposedNorrie Ross

BUSHFIRE victims had no idea they were in danger from ``atomic force'' fireballs on Black Saturday because Victoria's warning system broke down.

The opening day of the bushfire royal commission was told people stayed in their homes unaware of the inferno approaching.

Counsel assisting the commission, Jack Rush, QC, said the warning system failed to cope with the speed of the fires and the public had no accurate or timely information.

He said the ``stay or go early'' warning system might have misled people who did not understand what they were facing.

The 000 emergency line and other warning systems would also be examined.

``Why would a resident of any of the fire-affected regions implement the `go' part of the policy if they were not aware of any fire threat?'' Mr Rush said yesterday.

``(People) who chose to stay and defend their properties did so entirely unaware of the severity, the extremity, the intensity of the fires they would face.''

The bushfire disaster killed 173 people.

Continued Page 4

From Page 1

The opening day of the commission was dogged by complaints that individual survivors were being denied the right to give evidence.

There were complaints the commission had been hijacked by the interests of government departments, councils, emergency services, insurance and power companies.

Mat Tinkler, of the Public Interest Law Clearing House, said applications from the 30 individuals and communities he represented were rejected without their barristers even getting the chance to put their case.

``Money is no object for the big players, who are briefing the country's top lawyers to appear,'' Mr Tinkler said.

``. . . bushfire survivors and communities that were devastated by the fires have been provided with no funded assistance to seek leave to appear or make submissions.''

Premier John Brumby refused to buy into the argument over representation.

``I'm not going to comment on the specific decisions made by the commission,'' he said.

``I made it very clear that I wanted this to be a commission for the people.

``I wanted to have the broadest possible terms of reference and that's what we put through the Parliament.''

Commission chairman Bernie Teague said leave to appear was granted to a limited number of applicants. He strongly urged others to have their say in written submissions.

In his opening address, Mr Rush said the forest fire danger index had predicted February 7 would be the worst fire danger day ever in Victoria.

A figure of 50 was considered ``extreme'', but on Black Saturday it ranged between 120 and 180. In such catastrophic conditions normal warnings became useless.

``The risk that the index indicated carried with it the potential of a fire that could not be fought,'' he said.

Mr Rush said the first issues considered would be the warnings and the ``stay or go early'' policy.

An expert will give evidence to the commission that people have no knowledge of the triggers of when to leave early and when it is too late to leave.

Mr Rush said on Black Saturday Victoria recorded its highest temperatures since records began in 1859, soaring into the high 40s and with winds over 100km/h.

He said the primary concern of the commission would be to make recommendations that saved lives. The commission will hand down an interim report by August 17 and a final report by July 31 next year.

Editorial, Page 22

urn:contentItem:7VKK-32T1-2RYX-12YX-00000-00LETTERS TO THE EDITOR2009-05-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisPg. 18LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

Transaction taxes poor policy

The State Government, as it contemplates its declining financial woes, would have us believe it has no control over its problems, blaming ``global forces''. But it has foolishly chosen its path, and must now live with the consequences.

Reliance on transaction taxes (stamp duties, etc) was always poor policy. Those of us who attempted to sound the warning were ignored, and will now have to pay the price of government folly. That will be reduced services and a lesser future.

At the federal level, the GST was touted as the great growth tax -- the teat for the states to suckle. Doesn't that seem absurd now? It always was, of course. It is obvious that any tax on transactions will lead to less transactions -- just when we need more of them.

The option ignored by all levels of government has been a flat tax on land values. It would encourage and reward enterprise, satisfy social equity issues, and would continue to fund all public services.

Most importantly, it would dampen the cause of property booms, and thus avoid the busts.

Most economists agree that a tax on land is the least distorting tax. So why hasn't it been introduced? For a clue, check out the donors to the major political parties.

Leo Foley, Secretary, Prosper Australia

The rich are the wrong target

It seems both the Federal and State Labor governments are playing the game of politics of envy by targeting the well-off under budgetary changes.

It is good to target people earning big salaries or incomes, for the opinion polls. And having a federal government dominated by former union officials, you cannot expect much else. But these policies can have a very negative result on two fronts. The first is that those who have the income now are the ones who are keeping our service industries going through their ability to spend. Reduce that and you risk jobs.

The second is that it takes away the incentive for people to get ahead because they know the government will penalise them for their effort.

This also has a negative effect on Jobs. Stimulate the economy all you like, politics of envy will kill it.

Graeme Matthews, Old Beach

Asylum-seeker politics of fear

Recently, Australians have suffered the politics of fear and ignorance peddled by the Liberal Party (``Another asylum-seeker boat'', Sunday Tasmanian, April 26).

Dr Herbert Vere Evatt and Jessie Street had a significant role in the drafting of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in 1945.

I want to remind your readers of the terms of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

Article 14 says simply: ``Everyone has the right to seek and to enjoy in other countries asylum from persecution.''

Not a word about detention centres.

And because of that, I think today is an appropriate occasion to call for the immediate closure of immigration detention centres.

John Ward, Gordon

Fencing rethink needed after fire

The recent Epping Forest fire clearly demonstrated that roadside fencing constructed using only treated pine strainer assemblies and posts and droppers can be totally destroyed by fire.

This allows stock to escape on to roads, creating an additional traffic hazard.

The use of metal strainer assemblies and droppers on at least every second post, while not entirely solving the problem, will at least leave the majority of fences standing and stock-proof after such a fire.

Lindsay Millar, Hillwood

urn:contentItem:7VH0-C6H1-2RG6-Y54R-00000-00Fire commission to consider fuel reduction burns2009-04-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisLateline8:44 PM AESTABCRafael EpsteinFire commission to consider fuel reduction burns

TONY JONES, PRESENTER: The Royal Commission into Victoria's bushfires began its first formal proceedings today. Among many issues, the Commission will consider the vexed question of fuel reduction burns and whether enough was done before the fires struck. Figures presented to a Labor-dominated parliamentary committee show there were minimal fires in areas of Victoria where fuel reduction targets were met. But some of the communities worst hit by the fires are in regions where the Government didn't meet its own targets for back burning. Rafael Epstein reports.

RAFEAL EPSTEIN, REPORTER: This Royal Commission will consider questions they tackled after Ash Wednesday and Black Friday in 1939.

BERNARD TEAGUE, ROYAL COMMISSIONER: Why from were those bushfires so extreme, so feral, so catastrophic, so devastating?

RAFEAL EPSTEIN: On the agenda will be back burning, or fuel reduction burning, by the agencies of the State Government.

JACK RUSH, COUNSEL ASSISTING: The purpose of prescribed burning is not to prevent fire from occurring, but to reduce the intensity of fire, it's rate of spread and the difficulty of suppression.

RAFEAL EPSTEIN: The commission will be going over old ground. A report last year from a Government-dominated parliamentary committee in Victoria recommended they almost triple the amount of back burning. Data presented to that committee shows the fires on Black Saturday were less fierce in the regions where fuel reduction targets had been met.

In the regions known as Port Philip, the north east and Gippsland, the state's Department of Environment and Sustainability had trouble reaching its burn off targets because of adverse weather and others reasons.

Those regions contain the places worst hit in February - communities like Kinglake, St Andrews and Churchill.

In regions like the south west and the north west fuel reduction targets mostly were met, in part because the forests there are easier to get into. The towns that suffered during Ash Wednesday this time were left untouched.

JACK RUSH: It has been said once a fire has started, fire intensity and the speed in which fire spreads are affected by fuel loads. Of three factors influencing fire behaviour, the quality and arrangement of fuel is the only factor that can be altered by man before an unplanned fire starts.

RAFEAL EPSTEIN: The Victorian Government says there's been more fuel reduction than ever before, but they say it's no panacea.

JOHN BRUMBY, VICTORIAN PREMIER: There are some parts of the state that I've seen in my visits where fire reduction - fuel reduction burning has occurred in the last two or three years, but it didn't start the fire. There are parts of Gippsland where that occurred, where it just swept through, irrespective of the fact there'd been fuel reduction.

RAFEAL EPSTEIN: The Commission will also look at the fire conditions predicted for the day.

On the Wednesday before the fires, emergency services received a recorded forecast, predicting that the fire danger index they used would hit unprecedented levels.

FIRE DANGER ANNOUNCER (recorded forecast): Forest fire danger ratings and grassland fire danger ratings both will peak in the 80s in the latter half of the morning.

RAFEAL EPSTEIN: Such forecasts prompted the dire but general warnings from Government and officials the sorts of figures that counsel assisting said should've prompted these thoughts within government agencies.

JACK RUSH: The intensity of the potential fires would be such that it could not be imagined by our generation.

RAFEAL EPSTEIN: The first hearings begin next month. Rafael Epstein, Lateline.

control</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Los Alamos, New Mexico</p><p nitf:lede="true">AN army of 1000 fire fighters on the ground and in the sky struggled yesterday to contain a wind-driven forest fire that forced thousands of people from their homes, caused $1 billion in damages and charred vast areas at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, the top US nuclear research facility.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Despite their efforts, the mighty blaze spread like a fast-growing cancer across more than 14,600ha of scenic northern New Mexico, sending up huge plumes of smoke that were visible for hundreds of kilometers.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Officials had expected cooler temperatures and calmer winds to help them get a grip on the fire, which was deliberately set last week as part of a forest management program to avert just such disasters.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Reuters</p></bodyText></section><p>But on Saturday afternoon officials said winds had kicked up again and left them scrambling to hold on to the 5% of the fire they had contained on Friday night.</p><p> US Forest Service fire information officer Jim Paxon said yesterday: "This thing is growing and we don't know where it's going to end up.</p><p> "It will be a long time before we get this fire contained . . . this fire is going to burn for weeks."</p><p> Paxon said the fire, which had so far destroyed 261 homes was spreading in three directions all around the Los Alamos laboratory and was near a town and two Indian reservations.</p><p> "We just simply don't have enough people power and machines and aircraft to just stop it right now," he said.</p><p> Officials said more than 1000 firefighters using hand tools, heavy equipment and fire hoses were battling the flames, aided by a fleet of 18 firefighting airplanes and helicopters dumping water and fire retardants.</p><p> Along with the winds, Paxon said the fire was being fuelled by the effects of a prolonged drought that was the most severe in New Mexico's recorded history, dating back to the 1700s.</p><p> President Bill Clinton yesterday declared a 12-county region of New Mexico a disaster area.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4632-BWV0-015G-S2WJ-00000-00<published>2002-06-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 20</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest worker lit huge Colorado fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DARRELL GILES</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A US Forest Service employee has been charged with starting the Colorado Rockies fire that has damaged 40,000ha and threatened the homes of 45,000 residents.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Forestry technician Terry Barton, 38, admitted starting a campfire, but it got out of control. Then she tried to cover up her involvement.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Barton was patrolling the forest, warning campers about the dangers of accidentally setting off a massive forest fire. There was a fire ban in part of the forest.</p><p> She said she started burning personal papers, a letter from her estranged husband, within a designated campfire ring, where fires normally would be allowed, and then tried to put out the blaze.</p><p> Bill Leone, of the US Attorney's Office, said Barton told investigators she reported a fire -- but not that she had started it.</p><p> This led the Forest Service to question what she was saying.</p><p> "She attempted to suppress the fire, but it grew," Mr Leone said.</p><p> Barton was charged with setting fire to timber in the national forest, damaging federal property in excess of $US100,000 ($A175,800) and making false statements.</p><p> If convicted, she faces up to 10 years in prison and $US250,000 ($A446,430) in fines.</p><p> She was scheduled to make an initial court appearance in a Denver federal court today.</p><p> "This is one of the hardest announcements I've had to make in my career," said Rick Cables, regional forester for the Rocky Mountain Region for the US Forest Service. "I'm shocked and with a lot of other people, in a state of disbelief. I'm saddened to say that one of our employees has admitted to starting the Hayman fire."  Twenty-two homes were destroyed in the blaze. Firefighters gained ground on Sunday on the wildfire that had burned within 75km of Denver city limits since it was started on June 8.</p><p> With the blaze about 35 per cent contained, some 5400 people remained out of their homes.</p><p> Another blaze flared in southwest Colorado and forced the evacuation of more than 330 homes. The latest fire had burned more than 10,000ha in the San Juan National Forest.</p><p> Brush and wildfires also were burning yesterday in other areas of the drought-stricken west, including California.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49K3-JP70-01S8-G4BR-00000-00<published>1987-05-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>FOUR FACE DEATH ON CHARGES THEY LIT CHINESE BLAZE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>COSTELLO D</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Four face death on charges they lit Chinese blaze PEKING._ Two workers who lit cigarettes and two others who ran machines illegally in a dry forest have been arrested for starting the biggest forest fire in communist China's history.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>The workers face execution for allegedly causing the deaths of almost 200 people in a fire which blackened about 1 million ha before being brought under control on Tuesday. The Forestry Vice-Minister, Liu Guangyun, said there was no trace of sabotage behind the fire, which started in Xilinjizhen, Tuqiang, Amur and Tahe. Mr Liu said the most reliable casualty figures were 191 believed dead, 221 seriously injured and 56,000 people in almost 11,000 households affected. In the first detailed assessment of the fire's cost, Mr Liu said it had blackened 1 million ha of mainly forested land, destroyed 750,000 cubic metres of logyard timber and damaged 640,000 sq. m of buildings. He said direct economic losses, excluding standing timber destroyed and the cost of moving 40,000 firefighters to the scene, were estimated at between $153 and $188 million. Mr Liu said the three-week fire, which moved at speeds up to 60 km/h, caught soldiers and firefighters unprepared. He said people in Xilinjizhen fled naked in the night as the fire approached. He said another giant fire just across the border in the Soviet Union, which he described as three times bigger than China's, had also been put out. urn:contentItem:7V3D-4T50-Y9B7-72X3-00000-00Vic: Firefighters bracing for another scorcher on Friday2009-02-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:13ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVic: Firefighters bracing for another scorcher on FridayCatherine Best Michelle Draper and Jeff TurnbullMELBOURNE Feb 24

  Firefighters are still battling blazes on Melbourne's eastern fringes and in central Victoria ahead of what could be another horror day on Friday.
   The Country Fire Authority (CFA) has been able to downgrade urgent situations at Upwey in the Dandenong Ranges and at Daylesford northwest of Melbourne, but has warned residents to be alert.


   At Upwey, a fire that started in the Birdlands Reserve on Monday has been contained but the CFA has warned residents in adjacent areas to be on the lookout for flying embers in the tinder-dry conditions.
   "Even though the fire is not currently posing a threat, the communities of Upwey north of Glenfern Rd need to be aware that fire activity in the area has increased and has the potential to impact directly," the CFA said.
   CFA spokesman Kevin Monk said ground and air crews were working to prevent any spotting of the fire.
   He said 400 firefighters were at Daylesford, 110km northwest of Melbourne, attempting to contain a forest fire spread over 2,800 hectares.
   "We've got dozers working on that and that's where we may get some spots under the southerly conditions," Mr Monk told AAP.
   "The conditions are so dry that it only takes a small spark and the fire can race off."
   At Warburton, east of Melbourne, the threat eased after firefighters battled overnight to get on top of that blaze.
   But Mr Monk warned that conditions were likely to deteriorate on Friday with temperatures tipped to top 38 degrees combined with strong northerly winds and a south-westerly change.
   "Those conditions are always a concern for us and the possibility of new fires starting is a worry," Mr Monk said.
   "People in the community really need to be on alert for the day."
   Premier John Brumby said only rain can snuff out the fires.
   He said it was a miracle the blaze threatening Upwey was contained with minimal damage to property.
   "Last night was a miraculous effort really by the firefighters and they just did a fantastic job," he said.
   Mr Brumby said Friday was going to be another bad day for firefighters, with scorching heat set to return as 1,000 kilometres of fire fronts continued to burn.
   "(It's) nothing like February 7 in terms of temperature or wind but nevertheless we're looking at something at the top end of the 30s and in the north of the state the low 40s," he said.
   Australia's growing bushfire aid appeals will be further boosted with two massive benefit concerts to be held simultaneously in Sydney and Melbourne on March 14.
   Long disbanded groups are reuniting, a major cricket final is moving venue, and federal Environment Minister Peter Garrett will front Midnight Oil to help raise $4 million for bushfire victims.
   Several international acts will also take time out from their busy tour schedules to play for free at the bushfire benefit concerts.
   Kings of Leon and Coldplay will perform at the Sound Relief concerts at the MCG and the SCG while the Sheffield Shield final due to be held at the MCG on the same day will be moved to another venue.
   Hunters and Collectors will re-form for the event along with Split Enz and Icehouse.
   Tickets are $75 and will go on sale from Ticketek on March 4.

urn:contentItem:5D7N-29X1-JD3N-52GY-00000-00REEL FUN FOR KIDS ON LEAVE2014-09-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 26REEL FUN FOR KIDS ON LEAVELEIGH PAATSCH

Stumped about what movies to take the kids to this school holidays? LEIGH PAATSCH has everything you need to know about this end-of-term's crop of new releases.

GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY (M, 121 min) NOW SHOWING Who? Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana, and the voices of Bradley Cooper, Vin Diesel. What? Sci-fi adventure-comedy. A group of reformed space criminals must work together to stop a fanatic from destroying the galaxy.

Well ... ? The latest release from Marvel Entertainment is already one of the biggest films of 2014, and stands up well to repeat viewing. The M-rating is slightly deceptive, as a majority of scenes (save for the occasional explosion) are well inside the all-ages zone.

Which age group?

under 5yo: * 1/2 5yo - 8yo: *** 9yo - 12yo: **** 13yo+: ****

THE BOXTROLLS (PG, 99 min) NOW SHOWING Who?: The voices of Isaac Hampstead Wright, Jared Harris, Ben Kingsley, Elle Fanning.

What? Stop-motion animation. A young orphan raised by sewer-dwelling trash collectors tries to save his friends from an evil exterminator. Based on the children's novel Here Be Monsters by Alan Snow.

Well ... ? A strikingly animated production from the makers of the recent surprise hits Coraline and ParaNorman. If your kids could handle the creepier material that surfaced in those films, they should have no problems here. Otherwise, easily spooked young children might be better sent elsewhere.

Which age group?

under 5yo: ** 5yo - 8yo: *** 9yo - 12yo: *** 1/2 13yo+: ***

TEENAGE MUTANT NINJA TURTLES (M, 112 min) NOW SHOWING Who? Megan Fox, Will Arnett, Whoopi Goldberg and the voices of Johnny Knoxville, Tony Shalhoub.

What? Action adventure. With the help of an intrepid news reporter, a group of mutated warriors face off against an evil kingpin who wants to take over New York.

Well ... ? The Turtles are back, but not in the family friendly guise that most '90s nostalgists would fondly remember. The combat scenes are too violent for children, while the sleazy asides when co-star Megan Fox slinks into frame are an unwelcome bonus.

Which age group?

under 5yo: * 5yo - 8yo: * 9yo - 12yo: * 1/2 13yo+: **

PLANES: FIRE & RESCUE (G, 80 min) NOW SHOWING Who?: the voices of Dane Cook, Julie Harris, Julie Bowen, Brad Garrett. What? Animation sequel. When Dusty learns that his engine is damaged and he may never race again, he joins a forest fire and rescue unit to be trained as a firefighter.

Well ... ? Doesn't happen often, but this spritely and involving sequel marks a dramatic improvement upon what was only a so-so original. With so few low-impact "entry-level" titles for very young viewers this holiday period, this will be a reliable choice for most parents.

Which age group?

under 5yo: *** 1/2 5yo - 8yo: *** 9yo - 12yo: *** 13yo+: **

THE MAZE RUNNER (M, 117 min) NOW SHOWING Who? Dylan O'Brien, Will Poulter, Aml Ameen, Kaya Scodelario. What? Action adventure. Thomas is deposited in a community of boys after his memory is erased, soon learning they're all trapped in a maze that will require him to join forces with fellow "runners" for a shot at escape.

Well ... ? The M-rating is fully warranted because of the violence and a few threatening scenes, which means that it should be kept right away from young primary-schoolers. For boys 10 and over, though, this gripping chase flick will deservedly be their must-see movie of the holidays.

Which age group?

under 5yo: * 5yo - 8yo: * 1/2 9yo - 12yo: *** 13yo+: *** 1/2

THE HOUSE OF MAGIC (G, 85 min) NOW SHOWING Who? the voices of Cinda Adams, George Babbit, Murray Blue.

What? Animated adventure. Seeking shelter from a storm, a cheeky and lovable cat named Thunder sneaks into a mysterious mansion owned by retired magician Lawrence, aka "The Illustrious Lorenzo".

Well ... ? A cheery bundle of fun for the under-10 gang. Made in Belgium (but voiced in English), this modest affair doesn't follow the Hollywood lead of cramming every scene full of sight gags and over-chatty voice talent. This makes for a refreshing change.

Which age group?

under 5yo: *** 1/2 5yo - 8yo: *** 9yo - 12yo: ** 1/2 13yo+: *

THE GIVER (M, 97 min) NOW SHOWING Who? Brenton Thwaites, Jeff Bridges, Meryl Streep, Odeya Rush. What Drama. In a seemingly perfect community, without war, pain, suffering, differences or choice, a young boy is chosen to learn from an elderly man about the true pain and pleasure of the "real" world.

Well ... ? The best aspects of this intriguing future-shock drama will go right over the head of kids under 10. However, there is plenty of quality food for thought for the rest of the youth demographic, especially those impatiently waiting for the next Hunger Games.

Which age group?

under 5yo: * 5yo - 8yo: ** 9yo - 12yo: *** 13yo+: *** 1/2

THE LAND OF THE BEARS (G, 87 min) NOW SHOWING VIC-NSW-QLD, OTHER STATES TO FOLLOW. Who? Marion Cotillard (narrator).

What? Nature documentary. A rare look into the lives of the colony of brown bears on Russia's Kamchatka peninsula. Filmmaker Guillaume Vincent spent 500 days following a young cub leaving his home pack to go out on his own.

Well ... ? It has been a while since a strong feature doco struck a chord with family audiences. The 600kg stars of the show are a fascinating species that lead a tough life out on the Kamchatka, where it is winter almost nine months of the year.

Which age group?

under 5yo: *** 5yo - 8yo: **** 9yo - 12yo: ****13yo+: *** 1/2

urn:contentItem:4N09-G1K0-TX5M-4374-00000-00Towns to suffer2007-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 28Towns to suffer

OF 15000ha of forest in the Yarra tributaries Yarra Ranges only 60-70ha is harvested a year. Of the 50000ha in the Thompson Catchment only 12000ha is available for harvesting, of which a maximum 150ha is harvested annually.

The quality timber from this forest is the lifeblood for many small regional towns. To end harvesting would result in the closure of sawmills and, of course, job losses. The timber workers who make up these communities are quite often the backbone of local CFAs. If their jobs go so will they and in turn the people who fight bushfires.

Harvesting contractors, like their CFA counterparts, also provide valuable expertise in firefighting. Their machinery has been the difference between a small forest fire and a major wildfire. The timber industry has provided the road network that allows better access to fires. They are the ones who are protecting our catchments from fire.

Stopping the timber industry from having access to these areas will see the forest left relatively unprotected from fire. It would be a cruel twist of fate if the forests that the environmentalists had believed they were saving, burned, (as has nearly happened recently) because the machinery and people that would have been there had gone due to environmentalists locking up the forest.

Scott Gentle,

State manager,

Timber Communities Australia, Healesville.

Tour a successTHE Lilydale & District Historical Society would like to thank the Leader for its article on the old Lilydale Cemetery (January 22).

As a result of this the Australia Day twilights tour of the cemetery that was conducted by members of the society on Friday, January 26, was an overwhelming success, with about 120 people attending.

It was a beautiful evening and there was a great deal of interest in the remarkable stories of the lives of the people buried in the cemetery.

Thank you to the people who shared this experience with us. We hope it might spark an interest in the history of the town of Lilydale.

Sandy Ross, Lorraine Smith & Ruby Kwijas,

President & vice presidents of Lilydale & District Historical Society Inc.

Huge wasteMRS Fran Bailey, the federal member for McEwen, is at it again.

After 10 years of doing nothing about climate change and watching the demise of our great rivers, she and her colleagues have decided to spend $10 billion of taxpayers' money fixing the problem that they created.

Once again Mrs Bailey and her colleagues are asking taxpayers to foot the bill for their incompetence. And they also want to blame someone else. Let's blame the states, they said, for a system that's been in place for longer than she and her colleagues have been in office.

Where does it end, Mrs Bailey? Your head-in-the-sand attitude to environmental issues has cost taxpayers tens of billions of dollars and the environment dearly.

Peter Semple,

Panton Hill.

urn:contentItem:50YM-R711-JD3N-537M-00000-00Putin hints at 2012 run for president2010-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 12Putin hints at 2012 run for presidentRichard Beeston

SOCHI, RUSSIA: Vladimir Putin has come closer than ever to suggesting that he will run for president in 2012 -- raising the prospect that he could rule Russia for the best part of a quarter of a century.

Speaking yesterday in the Black Sea resort of Sochi, the Russian Prime Minister used the example of Franklin D. Roosevelt to suggest he, too, would like to run for president for two more terms, in addition to the eight years he has served in the Kremlin.

``There was a time when Roosevelt, the US president, was elected four times in a row because it did not run counter to the US constitution,'' he told the annual gathering of the Valdai Club, a group of foreign academics and journalists.

And, making the point that he was entitled to run for a second term, he added: ``Neither me nor President (Dmitry) Medvedev will do anything to run counter to the Russian constitution.''

He insisted the law would be followed to the letter and nothing would be done to ``hinder the democratic process''.

``We have been discussing a long time what should happen in 2012,'' he said. ``We will proceed from the real situation nearer the time.''

Mr Putin, looking tanned and relaxed, exuded confidence during several hours of questioning that covered foreign policy, the economy and his record in running Russia for the past decade.

Speaking in a former Soviet sanatorium, he made it clear by his response to questions that he remained the dominant figure in Russian politics, as opposed to Mr Medvedev, his former subordinate who is now head of state.

He certainly did not dispel the speculation about his future, which has intensified during his action-packed summer holidays, where even by his own bare-chested macho standards, the Russian leader has outdone himself in a series of transcontinental extreme adventures.

He drove across hundreds of kilometres of the Siberian tundra in a new canary yellow Lada, stopping to meet ordinary Russians along the way; he attended a motorcycle rally in Sevastopol complete with black leather biker's outfit and a Harley-Davidson; he got into the cockpit of a firefighting helicopter and doused the flames of a forest fire outside Moscow with a ``direct hit''; and took to the sea with conservationists to fire a crossbow bolt at a grey whale.

At every turn his carefully choreographed actions have been dutifully recorded on television and in the press. Few watching would have doubted that these were the actions of a man preparing his return to power in a typically energetic fashion.

The contrast with his diminutive political partner, Mr Medvedev, has been glaring. The President seemed to spend his summer anchored behind his desk in the Kremlin struggling to cope with one crisis after another.

Mr Putin said yesterday he was simply responding to the people's desire for effective leadership, suggesting the way he dealt with the fires around Moscow had been far more successful than US President Barack Obama's reaction to the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. ``People want the leadership to be solving problems, any problems that emerge, and they do not care about the methods used,'' he said.

During the final stretch of his trip across Siberia Mr Putin let slip that he was focused on returning to the Kremlin. The prospect of Mr Putin remaining in power for the next 14 years -- continuing as Prime Minister for two years and then as President for up to 12 years -- horrified the Russian opposition, who already engage in protests.

urn:contentItem:7V3K-FFG1-2RYX-13B0-00000-00Childs reborn Townsville will play host to a massive concert in 13 days as Jackson Browne headlines with Toni Childs and Richard Clapton in support. Childs was on a solo tour of Australia recently and ISIS SYMES caught up with her2009-02-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:12ZLexisNexisTHE GUIDEPg. 21Childs reborn Townsville will play host to a massive concert in 13 days as Jackson Browne headlines with Toni Childs and Richard Clapton in support. Childs was on a solo tour of Australia recently and ISIS SYMES caught up with herIsis Symes

SHE'S been recovering from a rare disease for more than a decade but American singer/songwriter Toni Childs is on top of the world.

The singer was recently in Australia to launch her first album in 14 years and a new range of organic products.

``It's been 11 years since I've been to Australia and it's so good to be back,'' Toni said.

Toni, whose career came to a grinding halt when she was diagnosed with a rare immune system disorder in 1997, is best known for her hits Don't Walk Away, Many Rivers To Cross and Stop Your Fussing.

She hit the big time in the late '80s, when her first album, Union, sold more than 500,000 copies in Australia. After a string of further hits, Toni succumbed to Graves disease and has spent most of the past decade recovering.

``When I contracted the disease I didn't know if I would ever be able to get back into music and tour so when I got back in the studio I was like a little kid stepping out of my skin, I love it so much,'' she said.

``I already had a large amount of songs ready to go right when I contracted Graves disease and had to stop my life.

``Going back into the studio I was able to record some of that plus the new stuff I had written and it just feels really good.''

Toni's music has evolved during her time away from the industry. ``What I'm doing now is rootsy and it's not done with drum loops or sequences or anything like that,'' she said.

`It's all organic and really old school. Every song is written on guitar so it has this rocky, rootsy kind of ode to some really great songwriters who inspired me earlier in my life like Neil Young, The (Rolling) Stones, Bob Dylan.

``The best part of re-emerging from the darkness and learning to embrace music once again, is simply the opportunity to evolve and get down to the core of my purpose.

``I feel like I'm a phoenix rising, burned down to an ash and then coming through that forest fire healthier and stronger than ever before.''

With word that she was back and raring to go in the music scene, organisers of Jackson Browne's world tour were quick to jump at the opportunity to have the singer on board.

``They knew I was touring again so I just got an invitation asking if I would like to do it and I said I would love to do it because I actually know Jackson and he's really good friends with my cousin so that was a really wonderful thing,'' Toni said.

TONI CHILDS

Toni Childs and Richard Clapton will support Jackson Browne at his Townsville Entertainment Centre concert on Tuesday, March 10. Tickets cost $98 pre-sold or $100 at the door. To book call the Box Office on 4771 4000.
